content:
Posted: January 20
Early Access Review
								I've played this game since it was a wee lad, about 2 months shy of nothing at all. Even then I was completely mesmerized. I'll state right off that I may be bias as this was the only game me and my brother could play together for several weeks running and I would certianly recommend playing w/ a friend(s) or expect to play online. Thats not to say there isnt an acceptable bot system in the game allowing you to play offline, but it just doesnt quite cut it honestly. This game isnt A+ but it is one of my favorite games. The scope of the gameplay is pretty amazing and with it's replayability factor, your gametime is only limited by your imagination. If you want some polished beautifully designed UI with top of the line graphics this may not be your thing but if you've ever watched Star Trek and wished you could somehow partake, this is about as close as it gets. Imagine, you can get your own star ship to roam around the somewhat depressingly doomed galaxy with a crew of your buddies. Take on your foes in adrenalizing firefights, cannons blasting away at your enemy's shield and hull as your reactor begins to heat up, all the while your men blaze away against an enemy boarding action in the lower decks. At the same time the enemy captain opens up comms and demands your immediate surrender. Just before he and his ship blow into a thousand pieces and you get to loot the remains and sell it for personal profit..

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28
Early Access Review
								Just a heads up, this game is not really a solo play game yet.  AI isn't all that great, and players will infuriate you.  That being said, its one of my current favorite games, and I want everyone to understand that in its current state, you need to play with others.To get the very best experience, I recommend you finding a friend that knows what they are doing and have them teach you  a role, or look for a friendly player when you join.  After you get the basics down, to get the very most out of this game, get a headset and join a game where everyone has a headset.  Communication is big in this game, and being a typer will hurt you in combat.Some big tips to the new players, when you join for some reason the UI doesn't show and voice chat isn't enabled.  You have to go to game settings (there are two options in the menu, edit game settings and game settings.  Go to just 'game settings') and enable both.  Go to the controls tab in options and set your push to talk key, which is on the third page on the left hand side.  It is defaulted to mouse 3 and T I believe to start, but if you are like me caps lock or pretty much anything is better than mouse 3. VR users, I've heard poor reviews about VR, and if you are looking for a good VR experience, I recommend looking elsewhere.  I could be wrong, I havn't tried it.  I want everyone to support the game, but a lot of negative reviews on this game is about the VR and lack of singleplayer due to poor ai. Here is a quick breakdown of the game:Graphics are mediocre at best. Sound is mediocre.Gameplay is amazing.Tutorial is poor.Combat is smashingContent is low for how many systems are in the gameRight now for a Beta or alpha, I'm going to give this game a thumbs up since it hits a unique take on working with a team.  I hope the devs reach the mark they are aiming for with this game, because if they do I think it will be a game that will be a shining example of space combat for big titles to have to follow.

Early Access Review
								An excellent starship simulator where you can take on the role of the captin, pilot, engineer, weapons specialist, or science officer and work together with friends or AI bots to explore the galaxy, fight against evil corporations, or an unknown plague.  Extremely in depth controls and options for each class as you have to control the functionality of the ship and it's exploration as only one of the members of the crew.  If something goes awry, you have to manually run to that section of the ship to take care of the situation in person as opposed to controlling the outcome via quick-time event.  Exceptionally well thought out and in-depth.  Highly recommended from a huge Star Trek, Mass Effect, and The Expanse sci-fi nerd.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								One of the funnest space games i have played.  When you get a descent group it's pretty amazing.  Engineer managing power, warp, and coolant.  Pilot aligning to warp point, or manuevering around in combat.  Scientist doing science things(uploading viruses, scanning the system or a particular ship).  Weapon specialist manning the guns, firing on enemy ships or shooting down missiles.  Captain barking orders, negotiating or intimidating the enemy, upgrading ship, setting crew member allowance for small arms, and setting the course for your adventure.  All of this while maintaining life support systems, your engine, weapon systems, while they take fire from enemy ships or catch on fire from being damaged.  You can also play with AI to kinda learn the controls and general layout of a ship, but it's not the same.That being said, there are a lot of reviews saying everyone is helpfull, and works together.  There are some, but with online games you will find trolls.  Usually they do their mischeif before you really embark on an adventure, so it really doesn't ruin a 4 hour run or anything - and hey, for a little bit - that is fun too.Totally worth the $24 for it - but if its on sale, snag this puppy.  I mean come on, who hasn't wanted to be scotty yellin, "i'm givin her all i got captain," while Kirk looks dramatically past the camera, while spock is telling him the unfortunate odds.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have to say having backed this game during its Kickstarter and having played very little of it, I have spent a long part of this weekend playing with a group of friends. My first impression was poor, and I really didn't think I would play it ever again.   However, this weekend has shown me how much fun it is, the graphics are simple and plain, the gameplay is fun, whether your crew is taking out enemy ships, or boarding the enemy vessel to take out the crew, or on a ground mission, the game is fun. Still feels a little empty in places, with planets seeming to have 1 or 2 buildings for the mission you're on, limited interactions, but it doesn't dent the fun factor.  Content can always be added, the difficulty is tough, but it is addictive.. Must have for groups of friends, its just good plain old fun, complex in places and satisfying once you crack it. I am very happy to report my initial impression was horrificly wrong, and I now will be a huge promoter of this game. I know we added 5 more players this weekend, and MORE will come.. I am so glad I backed this during Kickstarter..

content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
Early Access Review
Pulsar: Lost Colony is one of the best cooperative games I have ever playedThe graphics aren't that good, but noone really cares, because this game is awesome!The atmosphere and style is great, and the sound design is very nice.Everyone is dependant one one another. If one fails, everyone fails. And it's nice, because you can't be really good at this game, and just run the show all by yourself - you need other people.The gameplay is simple, but engaging - you manage your screens/tools, and follow the captain's orders.There are some simple shooting mechanics, and you can talk with all the npc's, and some of them have something genuinely interesting to say.With the constant updates, and attention to detail, the developers show, that this game is something they really want.It's nice to see that for once, and that they don't just take your money and run. (*cough* 'Ark: Survival Evolved' *cough*)The end game is where this game doesn't really shine that bright, given it is in early access. But that will eventually be solved.Overall, this game is great, but i suggest you buy it with at least 3 of your friends - it's going to be a lot more fun.Final Verdict: 8 / 10A great overall experience, that needs some polish and more content

Early Access Review
								Overall a great game in active development, especially if you wanted to command or operate your own ship with a team or friends. More fun with up to 5 real people that can run a ship, explore, blow stuff up, do away missions and more. Each person has a role, Captain, Science, Engineering, Weapons, and Pilot that requires everyone to work together to compliment each other's roles. Gain XP by exploring and doing missions/quests and advance your character. Board enemy ships (tricky with AI), and take them over for your command. It's still a work in progress but gets updates pretty regularly. AI has gotten a big improvement, quests are showing up, and the ships all feel very different and unique.Would definitely recommend this actively supported Work in Progress if you wanted to ever command or fly your own ship.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								Have you ever wanted to go on a space adventure with your friends? Does the idea of yelling over coms while you and your crew desperately try to survive entice you? Do you just want a good game to socialize in? If so, this is the game for you.You and your crew take on the galaxy in an attempt to get rich, pimp out your ship, and slaughter everything in your path. You will find yourself engaging in space battles, exploring planets, and completing missions in order to amass lots and lots of cash. Your travels will take you to many places, like desolate planets, abandoned ships, and the public toilets in a trade hub. This trek across the galaxy can be done by either friends or strangers you meet on the internet. The game is good as a social game since it requires you to actually communicate if you want any chance of getting anywhere in the game. Theres currently enough content in the game to give you a few 8-10 hour adventures. Each instance of a game generates a randomly laid out galaxy that is different from the ones you played before and the ones you will play in the future. Devs are pretty good about updating the game. Overall, definitely get. Great fun.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2016
Early Access Review
PULSAR: Lost Colony is a cooperative game in a futuristic space faring setting.  Up to five players collaborate to tackle exploration and combat objectives.  Each player assumes a role in a small starship crew: Captain, Scientist, Pilot, Engineer, or Weapons Specialist.  Working together, the crew travels across a randomized galaxy to overcome various obstacles.  Exploration missions task the crew with travelling to remote locations to retrieve items or investigate an area.  Combat includes ship-to-ship battles as well as gunfights between individual players and opposing NPCs.  Enemy ships may be boarded and seized, or destroyed for scrap.Each player has specific responsibilities.  The Scientist operates the ship's sensors, shield configuration, and opens communications with other vessels.  The Engineer manages the ship's power systems to ensure various parts of the craft are able to operate, without overheating the reactor.  The Pilot flies the craft and acts as the crew's "eyes" - identifying hazards or items of interest that do not appear on sensors.  The Weapons Specialist mans the ship's turrets and acts as the craft's security officer.  Finally, the Captain (the player hosting the game) is the crew's decision maker - managing missions, diplomacy over comms, and overseeing the crew's finances.Simply put, PULSAR: Lost Colony is a great game.  For a better understanding of the game (without playing it), check out this gameplay video.

content:

Early Access Review
								Loads of fun with friends, Got the game before it came out on steam early access and shows loads of promise!Get the game if you have another 3 great friends who want to make Star Trek references..That or have friends who know nothing about Star Trek and confuse the F**k out of them!So on to the pros:Great co-op gamePlays perfectly (They stated before they wanted to add more content they'd have a stable build of the core systems first)Interesting ship combat (Board em, shoot them, flee, scream nasty words at them)Massive GalaxyFlood/infection type of race thingiie that builds up over time (You can run but you can't hide)Nice FPS combat too (although could use more weapons other than different types of pistols)Now ze cons:Currently only 4 ships (more to be added soon)Can only have one ship in game (would be awesome to have multiple ships during a multiplayer game.)

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								BUY WITH WILLING FRIENDS!!What is it: FTL with Friends!This game is actually super cool! The whole idea and concept is honest just a dream game if you want to be running LANs or just want a good game for you and the buds!The basic idea is this, You and your friends are in charge of running a spaceship, so you'll need a pilot, a weapon specialist, a scientist, an engineer and of course, a captain. then you just go exploring the depths of space! completing missions and the like!PROS:Decent multiplayer! didn't have much trouble connecting, making a server, and the server lag wasn't ever a problem.Gameplay seems solid! the controls and weapons all seem to function well! the weapons aren't too exciting yet though.Pilot and run your own spaceship with your friends! This all works awesome! the piloting controls, and the whole UI is great if you are changing things in the menus and various panels found throughout your craft.Jobs are actually fun! the jobs are surprising all filled with interesting things to do at almost every moment of gameplay, no real down time or dull moments for anyone! though admittedly, Pilot and Engineer have the most to do, and the most responsibility.Go to planets! You can actually go to a variety of planets and fight monsters, aliens, robots or the general populace for the loot found about the place!You can level up and upgrade your character! You can actually pick from a decent selection of perks that improve your job efficiency, and get a variety of armours and weapons along the way!CONS:Shooting isn't so great yet: With the exception of spaceship shooting, the FPS gameplay is weak, but functional. with work, this will be much better in time I imagine!Planets can be dull: Some planets can be strange, or seem very.... glitchy. This part definitely feels the most unpolished, but I'm confident it will improve with time.Navigation can be awkward: Too often we got a mission at a such-n-such location, and we had no clue how to get there. I think some work needs to be done in this area.Progression is Minimal: The character progression is fine, but the ship progression seems non-existent. to my knowledge, you cannot upgrade your ship to another ship, merely attach upgrades to certain parts of the ship. This is all well and good, but once you start making coin, it would be cool to be able to buy a new spacecraft to use in game. THINGS THEY SHOULD INCLUDE IN THIS (AWESOME) GAME-Campaign Mode: A full story to experience with your friends spanning a good 6 hours or so! with firefights, exploration, science stuff, and diplomacy! I would love that kind of experience, making the tough decisions as captain, putting controversial decisions to a vote for your crew, or possibly facing Reaper-ish foes! It would be fantastic!-Custom-Made Missions: This would fit into the campaign side of things, but A mission builder type of system would be awesome! You could make entire missions or campaigns to then play with friends or share online, with the option of including voiced dialogue and tree-style story elements!-Launchable Starfighters: It would be awesome if in the event of a large battle, a launchable craft could be made available to aid the mothership in violent incursions! This could also open the door to additional exploration options!In closing, this game is freaking great! It is missing a little shine and polish, but is very reminiscent of the "Mount and Blade" series, which is definitely a good thing! just add a bit more scope, and some more cool doo-dads here and there, we have a true classic!

content:
Posted: July 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								Really fun game with friends. Note: Key Words WITH FRIENDS. The game isn't very polished but it has a lot of charm. The planets are not very large but are pretty diverse in their settings. Which is something I really appreciated.Space combat can either be very dragged out or very quick depending on the two ships. It's not that fun as there's not much skill required. It's just pretty much who has the better weapons/hull/shield. The programs can save you in times of dire need but I haven't had much success in using the offensive programs.Great game with friends. Had a ton of fun after learning who to trade salvaged cargo and got decent enough weapons to kill bandits with. Definitely needs polish though. And I'll say it, the game has a lot of potential. (Early access cliche but I feel this game could actually be great. Dev is very responsive and helpful)P.S. I only have 0.1 hours on record because I had to directly launch from .exe due to a problem with my undedicated nvidia gpu.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								PULSAR: Lost Colony is a great game, even with only 1/10 of the intended content included so far. For all its roughness (being an early-access game) I have had a ton of fun with it so far and it is well worth the money even in its current state. The game feels very grand--moving from space station to ship to planet gives the impression that the universe is a huge place with many things to see and explore. I haven't tried all the crew positions yet; can confirm that Captain and Pilot are both very fun.If you have at least one friend, buy this game. You won't be disappointed, and it'll only get better from here.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7
Early Access Review
								Played this game a lots with friends, and some without. Did many game with all ship and did all research possible and mission. And my opinion on the thing is kinda mixed up, more on the positive side tho. So from what i've experienced, i could say that sometime you find a game with people that want to play the game seriously, maybe sometime too much, but i think that fine. I play most simulation game in a serious manner, to immerse me in the experience. Really, if you can get some friends (at least one, but i suggest two) you can do a lots in this game. The AI on your ship is really bad, but its getting better with the modification to the crew panel priority. If you play with a friend, get it to be gunner and as captain you can pilot easily. The enemy AI is a little over reactive, but unless you just board everything, you shouldn't notice it that much. After a while, when you know about the game, you can easily upgrade your ship with the best main turret, without needing to have a strong ship, etc, so i find that having more cargo space is more valuable than having firepower at start. The game is definitivly not for everyone, but for the public its targeting, well its great.The Dev keep upgrading the game from time to time, its not really fast, but at least they do it. What i would like to see in this game:- Scientist hacking mini-game, because right now it pretty non-interactive. Click, its send the virus, now wait. Scientist has nothing more to do most of the time.- Engineer salvage mini-game as well, why not. I mean, its fine to have an arbitrary % of getting something, but i feel like giving the chance to the player to do something for the salvage would be cool, with scaling difficulty for end-tier system.- I don't have anymore idea for right now.

								This game gets better and better every time I play it.  It can be a challenging game right from the get go. content:

Early Access Review
								Great space team simulator with some awkward game systems, but absolutely still full of wonder. Difficulty that is soul-crushing at times, and AI that will let your ship crash into a black hole unsupervised, but still pretty great. An absolute blast with more than 1 player. If you're looking for a game where everyone has individual roles and strange adventures a la Star Trek, this is your game. Space Battles are hectic and thrilling, and planet exploring is tense. Even in its current state, the potential of this game is showing in spades.

Early Access Review
								So, Pulsar Lost Colony... What I have found is that the game usually goes in this order.You start a new game and become captain of your new ship, oh how amazing this ship is, some of your friends start joining and begin polluting your soundwaves with the sounds of their fire extingushers and the sound of the blasters as they start drawing profound images all over your ship. Next comes the unknown online players (if you have the game set to private) who, if your lucky, will not instantly try to sabotage your ship and then eject your core.Once your crew is settled in and you spend the next 20 minutes gathering the missions from the station and purchasing the upgrades you want from the store you warp to the next sector to begin actually playing the game. However once you arrive you find an enemy ship and then it proceeds to one shot you, destroying your ship instantly...Then you restart the game and it all repeats :D10/10 would repeat the cycle again

content:
Posted: January 3
Early Access Review
								I dont know where to start...If you like space and coop games stop reading this review, scroll up and buy it.If you need some more info to be convinced here are my impressions:- it's most fun with friends, but it also possible to find a decent crew in a public match, the game has very good integrated voice chat (based on teamspeak)- it's very cool to have so many things to do onboard of the ship, especially if your crew is not full (5 people)- dogfights are very fun, but hard and full cooperation is needed, since 3 roles are needed, and 2 support- quests are mostly of the fetch type- at the moment, game needs more content (planets, quests...)- charging warp, jumping, charging warp, jumping... gets repetitive- planets are quite small, planet bases are very dark, so it's a challenge to navigate (you do have a spotlight though)Overall very fun, but runs out of content in about 20 hours (or so I've been told, I'm not there yet) and then you place it in the corner for a month and then return

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2
Early Access Review
								I spent the first hour running amok in the starting ship. Every screen displays real updates about your ship. Every control panel functions. There is a six-step process to rebooting your ship which involves monster circuit breakers and touch screens nestled behind the warp core.On my second multiplayer stint, we contacted a smuggler in the back alley of a space station, escaped the clutches of corporate drone gunships and jetpacked through a vast ancient planetary ruin so cold our EVA suit glass frosted over. This is apparently just one mission in a randomized, constantly-evolving galaxy.The only successful missions I have flown required teamwork. Pilot has to orient the ship so that the weapons officer can see the enemy. Engineer has to juggle power between the engines, weapons, and the power-hungry jump drive. Captain has to order the crew to stop firing phase pistols at viewscreens during critical operations.Bottom line: this game is packed with detail, takes place in a changing universe, and requires multiplayer cooperation. If your dream is for you and your friends to take a starship and explore the dangers of deep space, this is your game. If that is not your dream, you are lying.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
Early Access Review
								Artemis Bridge Simualtor was a great little multiplayer bridge simulator, Pulsar takes this idea and evolves if further.Pulsar is a multi-crew ship bridge simulator & space 'endurance' survival game(no real ending, see how long you can last).The game has five roles to choose from:Command your crew and bark orders as the Captain, ram asteroids and space stations as the Pilot, make things blow up as the Weapons Tech, Scan the crap out of things and conduct cyber warfare as the Science Officer, Overload the reactor and talk like a vertically challenged scottish bloke as the Engineer.Playable with 2-5 players(can play solo but AI is DAF) explore the galaxy, send away teams to hijack repair stations for free repairs, raid alien planets over run by hostile robots, shoot other ships and or take on quests to earn extra credits from space stations.In a nutshell, the game is a simple skill point based item hunting game where currently your main object to survive is to gear up your ship and know when to run or fight.It is a simple game at its core that is fun to play with friends and well worth checking out if you like the idea of crewing a spaceship with your friends.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								A great game for fullfilling any Star Trek fantasizes you may have left in your life. The captain is the captain, the gunner does gunner things, the engineer is micromanaging, the pilot flies the ship, and the glorious science officer is the medic and Electronic warfare operator. As the best (And only) Medic my crew has ever had we did a decent job at preforming our scouting missions and destroying the pirates. Unfortunately our pilot had no close quarters skills, the captain didnt use the chair (which i often stole :3) and the red shirt (Gunner) really did die in every engagement while i spent most of my time staring at a space ipad and healing, while on the ship i usually just ran comms and argued with the engineer over our use of power on certain systems, which did nearly cause us to crash into the side of a space station because we managed to turn off all of the power to the ship during a warp. A glorious game that just needs more content but is pretty great as it is.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								First review ever on my account with over 300 games because this one blew me away. Basically Faster Than Light redesigned as an online coop first person game. All PvE. You can even board other ships with your crew and steal them and extract some of the gear from your old one. There are some glitches here and there but they seem far from game breaking, but they could maybe become more aparant when I learn more about the game and be captain of my own ship. For example, the computer often says a system has no planet, but we go there and it does. But the bugs seem pretty minor and not too common from having played mostly as crew members for 20 hours now.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								The game is fairly light on hardware, but packs a lot more underneath. At the moment, the game has a few recycled textures which allows it to run fast. The ships at the moment are limited. However with the introduction of the Roland-class, we can see a potential for larger ships and perhaps hybrid AI/Human crew. Each ship has their own unique traits or abilities which allow for different styles of play. However the end game items overshadows these abilities which results in the same endgame play. Ship systems as of Beta 1 are moderately balanced however with AI controlled turrets, the main turret becomes less of a priority to man since the AI can hit it's target most of the time when you have a good pilot.The ground combat at the moment is a good step in the right direction. Variable landscape that change how the player has to adapt. The new environmental suits allow you to travel to dangerous locations without harm and the weapons are based on a tried and true trade-off method (one shoots fast but weak, one shoots slow but fast, etc.). At the moment, the gameplay requires players to dodge gun fire or melee attacks. Requires every little tactical movement when shooting back so players can easily duck behind cover to protect themselves. Player customization is fairly fixed on implants and tattoos, but allow for colour changes. Otherwise the customization is vast on hairstyles, facial and colour options. Like to see more in the future from Leafy Games, but I would deem this a playable Early Access and recommendable to anyone who enjoyed Star Trek: Elite Force with a mix of Artemis Ship Simulator.(Psst, my YouTube Channel if anyone wants a peak of all the things that have progressed in game: https://www.youtube.com/user/nawkcire)

Early Access Review
								PROS: Very cool concept(would love to see more of this style of game). Good devs. Lots of potential. It is funny how easily random people who join your crew can get into their roles both in terms of mechanics and role playing. The Captain is usually treated as the Captain and so on. There is a large galaxy to explore. Upgrading your ship and crew skills adds some sense of progression.CONS: The content in the game is quite limited at the moment(though there is enough to sink your teeth into). The graphics are basic but it still has a decent aesthetic.I look forward to the eventual fleshing out of ship's systems, crew abilities, AI interactions, missions, and planetary exploration. Like I said there is a lot of potential and a lot of features that can be added.At around 17 hours I feel I have gotten my money's worth so anything extra is just icing on the cake.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								5 Players team up to pilot a starship to adventure. What can go wrong?This can be an extremely fun game to play if you get a good dynamic crew. Captain matters most. Thus far I have only been Pilot and Captain, but I got us into some serious adventures as Captain. Ive been under the command of other Captains that were kind of dry and not so exciting - you need a Captain willing to do some crazy sh. You will also need to really learn your roles. Captain is a decision maker and really only needs knowledge of how to pilot and man a gun. But if youre Science Officer or Engineer, you need to know what youre doing. A good Science Officer and Enginneer are crucial to getting you OUT of situations the Captain gets you in to. This game seems very deep and involved after you start learning it. Its pretty much everything No Mans Sky should have been. This game is one of the most promising and exciting EA titles Ive ever played. There are a few cons though. The graphics look like something from 2000, which is fine - but with a graphical overhaul, this game woiuld be utterly amazing. The space graphics are fine - its the the FPS environments that are old-school. The gameplay more than makles up for this though. Recommended? Absolutely.One of my first real adventures found me as a new Captain. Our Weapons Officer had a lot of experience and was somehow assigned to our ship, crewed by newbies. We encountered a very tough and very well armed friendly ship. The weapons officer spied something he wanted - that ship's cannon. Well, we cant fight this ship, because it has a cannon that can obliterate us in short order in direct combat. However, we formulated a plan to take the ship.. Two of us had to beam over after we hit it with our main cannon one time, just enough to drop its shields. The pilot had to keep us under it so it cant hit us with that dreaded cannon. We hit it hard, beamed over, and got intp a firefight with its crew. Our Engineer got to their Engineering deck single handedly while I held the remaining crewman at bay in the teleport room, and shut the ship down. The rest of our crew beamed over and helped us slay the remaining crewmen. The ship was now ours. I claimed our new pride and joy amid cheering of our ragtag crew. Then the news came from Weapons Officer Barbosa: We were now marked as Pirates.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								I cant say enough great things about this game.  The developers are true gamers, they seemed to add in everything you could of ever wanted to a co-op space sim. It is still early but the game shows a huge amount of promise.  Dont go in expecting next generation graphics like ARK or flawless AI, go in looking for something orginal and well thought out.  Pros: Unique play style.  Nothing really like this out thereEveryone has a job to do.It really is epic.  They have a cool piloting mode that lets you fly the ship with wasd and the mouse. You just have to experience it.Quest...check.  Huge random open world...check.   RPG elements...check.  Random encouters...check.  Ship to ship combat...check.  Board enemy ships or get boarded...check.  Beam down to planets...check.  Fly in wrecked stations for loot...check. Cons:AI helpers are ok at best.  They pilot like crap and barely do anything more than take fire when you are boarded.  The developers are working on that.Character graphics are just plain bad.  Doesn't really bother me but some people might have a problem.  It is about game play and it is in beta.You need friends.  Get on reddit or look at forums plenty of people out there who want to fly if you dont have any buds.Wood panels on the floors in spaceships.  Dont know how I feel about that.Final thoughts:Pulsar brings a lot to the table and in a very early version is more than playable for many many hours.  If the big boys like Elite, SC or STO every figured out how to implement this level of co-op into thier games we would have a tough time figuring out what to play.  This is what STO should of been and what Elite and SC could have to make them true winners.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is a brilliant game, you are part of a crew of 5 on a space ship, you can play with real players or with bots. When you're playing you're not just pressing E (or in this case R) on a console and that automatically cools the core, you need to lower that power usage or turn on the coolant (or both). Are the programs out of charge? Get your butt in engineering, load that fuel cell, and pull that lever. Want to know what that enemy ship has, scan it and see its power usage, components, status, and what type of ship it is.You play as one of five roles, The Captain, The Pilot, The Weapons Specialist, The Engineer, and The Scientist.The Captain is self-explanatory, they orders the crew around, and is in charge of trading, diplomacy, that sort of stuff.The Pilot is also obvious, they pilot the ship, evade, align the ship, and give weapons a clear shot.The Weapons Specialist is usually controlling a massive super cannon, which is fires powerful lasers and missiles.The Engineer keeps the ship cool while at the same time giving everyone else enough power to work with.The Scientist will perform research, cyber warfare, scanning, and is generally the go to guy for getting to know what's going on.You explore though space, teleporting onto stations, exploring planets, and trying to find the Lost Colony.The website probably explains it better than so here Link to website[www.pulsarthegame.com]tl;dr version: Starship simulator when those buttons actually have a purpose.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								[DISCLAIMER]: Everything I say here is of MY opinion. Don't get all mad because it doesn't allign with your opinion.I have been following this game since it first came out on greenlight. This was around the time I still played Artemis: Spaceship Bridge Simulator and what this game promised was that game, but ten billion times better. First person ship bridge simulator is exactly what I wanted and I'm happy to say, this game delivers like there is no tomorrow.The game like I said is a first person multiplayer spaceship exploration/combat simulator. I first got the game when it was in early alpha and even though it was very rough, the game still had tons of features and charm. You and perferably 4 other friends begin their journey on one of the five ships avaible (ATM) each with its own personal style of play and interior/exterior looks. One of the things I was really looking for in this kind of game was ship system interaction. By this I mean as a player I control the ship in anyway I want. Its not just go forward and back, shoot weapons, and so on, I can control where the power goes around the ship, I can scan the sector for enemies, I can use programs that boost stats or viruses that infect enemy computer, I can tweak what subsystem need power from lights to atmospherics. The goal of the game is go through this procedurally generated galaxy and kill enemies for scrap. Once you do so you buy upgrades at shops and equip them on your ship. After this you will eventually be powerful enough to take on the galaxy boss and claim victory. On the way to this main goal there is so much to do and see so lets go over some of that.Things to do:1. Kill enemies.2. Loot abondoned space stations and structures for scrap all while avoiding dangerous mines.3. Find a high class enemy ship and prepare to board!4. Kill everything last thing on this enemy ship and hack is subsystems to take control of it!5. Use your new sexy ship to fly to a planet.6. Use your teleporter and beam down to the surface.7. Don't forget your space suit because humans need oxygen.8. Explore abondoned strucutes on the surface for food, weapons, collectables, and more!9. Tell your friend to walk out into the desert by himself/herself but DONT tell him/her about the evil sand worm.10. Find sector 0 and enter the famous Colonial Hub and meet new people and accept quests!11. Get lost in the Colonial Hub12. Fly into a sector with either a high level enemy or many enemies13. Panic because you shields are down14. REALLY panic because your ship is blaring its sirens and there are lots of red lights and evERYTHING IS SHAKING OH GOD15. Die16. Return more motivated than ever.16. Pay taxes to use the Long Range Warp Station to move around faster.17. Spend skill points to make yourself and your kick♥♥♥♥♥crew even better!18. Customize your apperance.19. Try to overthrow the captain.20. Fail at mutany21. Get ingrossed in something and forget about the heat level of your reactor.22. Panic AGAIN because all your system turned off due to emergency cooling.23. Wonder what this switch does and eject your loving core out into space (What did it ever do to you!?)24. Run out of fuel and have to open up your emergency broadcast beacon.25. Pray to the space whales that someone nice will come to your aid.26. Die from someone not so nice.27. Get determined to win the game (or at least progress as far as you can in the games current state)28. Do the process all again but not die29. Get hype for you epic finale boss.30. Pump your epic music so that your parents get annoyed.31. Shoot the crap out of the boss using your skills and that handy dandy nuke you forgot about.32. Revel in your victory and attempt to self destruct the ship.33. Die34. Give this game a thumbs up on Steam because of how awesome it is!What I covered about is not all that you can do. Its an open world space game so you can make up stories, role play, and gather your buddies for a awesome LAN party thats not actually LAN because the game doesn't have that feature yet BUT it will. Anyways this game is great on almost all sides. I didn't even mention it but the art style is very clean but detailed and easy to look at. All in all I can give this game tons of my love and I think you should too! If your reading this and you know you could even slightly enjoy this game then you should really click that buy button. Lastly the devs to this game are super open about their development and are awesome dudes. They would love to help you with problems and so would the Pulsar community. The devs even have had polling sessions to vote on content that will be in the game! So buy the game or don't, if you don't your missing out on the best open world spaceship bridge simulator to date.If you would like to see more I have a series of the game where me and some friend try our best to plow to the final boss. I will put a link to the first episode if you want to watch it. If not then don't, this isn't ment to be some plug or whatever but if you must think that it is, then i'm shamless about it :) Take care.

			The start of an epic journey beings here with the first installment of Pulsar: Lost Colony! CHANNEL: http://www.youtube.com/user/dyfe123 SECONDARY CHANNEL:...

Then a number rang in my head $40000 for some pistol the crew had been raving about money,money where can i ahem check that (bottom right )ah i was tabbed and and the bottom was covered by my start menu due to how i usually move my games, some Real immersion was setting in so i change to full screen (No more Music I was In)more battles took place as a Bond formed, we where a brother hood -Cept for that Little Devil who ejected our coolant,kept raming the repair staion,tossed our fuel And Manipulated Flow charts on MY Acuracy in the heat of battle.No i take that back He to is a brotherHow do i Say Thank You . number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								As of this writing, the game is currently on version 0.9.2A very fun co-op experience that's a little light on endgame content at the moment.The general description of the game is a five player co-op game where each player takes a specific officer role aboard a starship. These five players working together allow the ship to be run at prime efficiency as they explore uncharted star systems and engage enemy combatants on the ground and in space. Five people are not needed to play this game. I think 3 is a perfect minimum to make things run smoothly. The Captain would also play the role of pilot while two others were Engineer and Science Officer. You could then set two bots (Weapons Bot and Pilot Bot) to man the guns.A more in-depth description follows:PULSAR allows up to five friends to take on the role of a starship crew. While any player in any role can do any job, each role has specific perks that make them perform their role more effectively.The first role is Captain. The captain is in charge of the ship. He plots the course that the ship will take, manages ship finances and upgrades, gives an allowance to the other members of the crew for personal purchases, decide when to charge up the warp engine and initiate warp as well as how to respond to other vessels. He can take a diplomatic approach, militarisic approach or even extort other ships over the communications system. His skills are based on speech as well as allowing other players to move more quickly.The second role is Engineer. The engineer is the one who keeps the ship running. He manages the reactor which supplies power to the entire ship, juggling systems by diverting power to and from ones in need and making sure it does not overheat, charging the warp drive as well as actually initiating the jump upon the captain's order. His skills are designed to make his job easier by making reactor coolant more effective, allowing ship critical systems to begin self repairs, reducing the likelihood of fires during combat and increasing the chances of successfully obtaining working salvage from destroyed ships.The third role is Science Officer. The science officer has two primary roles aboard the ship plus a handful of secondary roles. His most important one is managing the cyberwarfare suite during combat. Managing computer viruses designed to perform actions such as kill an enemy's engines, stop their shields from recharging, siphoning credits and blocking long range distress communications as well as running anti-virus programs when his ship is the target of cyber warfare. His second role is research and developement. When research materials are brought aboard, the science officer can study them in order to learn new skills that can affect the crew in a myriad of ways such as faster weapon cooldowns, being able to run while encumbered and more efficient jetpack fuel. Other roles involve scanning ships and planets for lifesigns, EM, radiation and abnormal/dangerous weather conditions. His skills are designed around making shields more efficient, reducing the ship's signature to make detection more difficult and healing nearby crew members.The fourth role is Weapons Officer. The weapons officer's primary role is to man the ship's weaponry, including turrets, the main gun, missiles and nuclear armament. He is also responsible for leading the away team when boarding enemy ships or teleporting down to a planet. His skills revolve around making ship weaponry more efficient by reducing cooldowns.The last role is Pilot. The pilot's job is to fly the ship, primarily during combat, but also to align the ship with the target sector prior to engaging the warp engines. He is also responsible for getting the ship close enough to gather scrap off of destroyed ships and maneuvering into repair doks. His skills are designed to make the engines more efficient.

Early Access Review
								Forget traditional space 4x's, forget your Elite & Star Citizen, this game gives you the real sci-fi (star trek) experience. This is the game STO wishes it was. If you love sci-fi shows, you're going to love this. break out your mic and make sure nobody non-nerdy is listening and you'll have a blast. The game is missing some mid to high level content, and the universe feels a bit sparse and repetitive, but these are all normal things to be expected from a game that's allowed early access. It's a ton of fun now, and looks to be perhaps one of the most solid sci-fi experiences of all time with a little bit of future content.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								Ever watch Star Trek and say "I'd like to be one of the members on that ship"?Well, this game will allow you the opportunity to do just that!!!I have played thousands of games in my lifetime and I honestly can't say that I've enjoyed a game as much as this one in MANY years. I know the graphics look quite dated and it is true. This is not a game where you can expect to have everything glorified like you see in most new games out on the market. In a typical game you can start off pretty nice and relaxing at the controls and after a quick jump through space, your entire crew including yourself is thrown into a panic to man the guns and adjust power throughout the ship in order to ensure its survival. If you are a fan of star trek or have ever wanted to be part of that crew, do yourself a favor and get this game!!!If you enjoy coop games where everyone on the crew has a specific job to take care of, get this game.Cons to this game:-dated graphics, -Some games will have too many chiefs and not enough indians which makes gameplay really not enjoyable.All in all, find yourself a decent group of friends who are willing to teach you your job and let you at the controls no matter how often you may fail. This game is seriously under rated!!!!

content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								A very impressive game. 5 players get a spaceship, and adventure around the galaxy doing anything they like. The classes are all well designed, though the Scientist and Engineer could do with a few more responsibilities. The ships and their class-related functions are easy to learn how to use - after my first "game" (30 minutes of gameplay, "Game Over," everyone left) I had mastered a role and learned quite a lot about another two. The enemies (generally) aren't over- or under-powered, unless there are more than about 3 of them, in which case one should leave. Quickly.  One of my largest problems was the character model quality. While it doesn't affect gameplay, I'm very fussy when it comes to graphics quality. Also, there could be a bit more variety in terms of the ships (not the components, the ships themselves).I do think that the price was a bit too high, however. Personally, I would have been more willing to pay around £15, rather than £18.99. Alas, not many things are perfect - but this game isn't too bad.Rating:Concept: 9/10Graphics: 7/10Ships (Aesthetics & Stats): 9/10Story: N/AMap & World: 8/10Overall: 8.3/10

content:
Posted: September 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								An intriguing little game with lots of ambition. It aims to be a glorious mashup of Artemis: Spaceship Bridge Sim, FTL, Guns of Icarus, and Star Trek: Away Team, and while it is admittedly a little light on content at the moment, it does a great job of capturing the essential components and atmospheres of all these games.Players get to choose between four different ships to fly in, each with their own advantages and disadvantages, and five classes to play as: captain, pilot, weapons, engineering, and science, each with their own disticnt roles and RPG-style progression trees. At present, you start at The Hub, an expansive space station from which you can purchase items, weapons, and ship components, and also pick up various missions that drive progression in the game. Gameplay involves FTL-esque flight between randomized sectors, replete with derelict ships, crazed security bots, and enemy capital ships. There's also Away Team segments, where you can teleport down to nearby planets to fight the aliens de jour and search for your mission objectives. There are some neat metagame mechanics at work too: factions, reputation, and a Galactic Chaos system that ramps up the difficulty of enemies as you play. Apparently there are also some other surprises in store further out in the galaxy, but I haven't made it far enough out without getting vapourized to encounter them.All in all, it's a super promising little title with great atmosphere and ambition that's just a little short on polish and content at time of writing, but is still a blast to play. Best played with friends! You can yell at each other to charge the warp core as you are torn apart by AI bots. Overal Verdict: Pre-Beard Riker -- full of potential, and just waiting to fill out into a space-age icon.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is reminicent of FTL, but does plenty to differentiate itself from FTL.  It's in 3D and has 5 man online co-op featuring 5 unique roles: a Captain, a Scientist, an Engineer, a Pilot, and a Weapon's Specialist! Each role has it's own bonuses, a rudimentary skill tree, and different things to do such as steering the ship, hacking/scanning, manning turrets, fixing the ship or bossing people around. I've had some great moments in this game. As the engineer, there's nothing quite like pulling off Scotty like miracle work and saving the ship with last second engine repairs and then punching the button that jumps you all to safety. Similarly when there's a virus in the computer, rebooting the computer involves some Jurassic Park style flipping of big switches that always makes me chuckle to myself every time I see them! They're great. As the pilot I got to show off my piloting skills while gingerly easing the ship through the tight passages of an ancient wrecked structure and navigating around dangerous mines as we tried to salvage some loot. As the weapons specialist there was a moment when we bit off more than we could chew, with our ship blazing, and our weapons knocked offline I made a snap decision to board the enemy ship at the last second and managed to destroy their weapons, haulting incoming damage just long enough for my crewmates to jump the ship to safety. As the captain the first adventure was a blast, with me totally clueless but leading a crew of seasoned veterans, and they just rolled with it, bless them. It was a disaster, but everyone had fun. The scientist is the most underapreciated role, but they have their uses such as scanning for lifeforms and modulating shields. Although underappreciated, I take secret pleasure in joining a game as the scientist. I've heard rumours that there will be some form of scientific research added at a later date to flesh out the role a little more, and I do hope so.You can do some similar things in Pulsar that you can do in FTL such as boarding enemy ships, targetting their subsystems, hacking, shutting off their oxygen (or your own), causing/putting out fires, shopping, and upgrading your ship. There are some things you can do in pulsar that you can't do in FTL such as beaming down to planets, visiting space stations, comandeering enemy ships. There are some really nice touches, such as when you grab cargo, that stuff starts appearing on cargo pads in your ship. So when your ship fills up with cargo, it literally does fill up with cargo. Really adds to the immersion.The galaxy is open world which to me is a huge plus, so there's a lot of freedom to roam the galaxy as your captain pleases. The open world doesn't extend to planets, with surface areas being small areas around the teleporter pad, more akin to dungeons than planet surfaces. But they are certainly functional enough for their purpose.If you're lookng for something to play at the weekends with friends then there is definitely a lot of fun to be found here. Get 4 friends wth you and hilarity ensues. It was watching a live steam of people playing this that made me instantly buy it!If you're looking for an FTL-like game you can follow the development of and play occasionally when patches come out then this is a good buy. Judging from their past dev-videos, new content comes approximately on a monthly basis with bugfixes and tweaks more regularly. If you like the concept and are willing to support a dev on the potential of their game alone then you will probably not be disappointed, Personally, I played pulsar for 2 days solid, and stopped playing it, only because I don't want to play it to death at this early stage. I know there is still a lot of content needs to be added and so it's better to only dabble in it for now. So now I just play it for a bit when patches some out.  The base game is complete, and all the core mechanics have been fleshed out to where it's a fully fledged game. There is a large galaxy to explore and missions you can play through. All that is lacking is a decent variety of content to keep things interesting in the long run. To be sure if you're looking for something that you can play all day long, every day, and never run out of content, then this is not the game for you--at least not yet. But if you're looking for something to dabble in until the developer has a chance to flesh it out more then I heartilly recommend.As with all Early Access games there's no guarentee it will ever be finished, So really it comes down to whether you're willing to support the developer on the merit of what they have right now and on the future potential. Keep in mind your idea of "fleshed out" might differ from the developers. I've been burned before, *cough* Elite Dangerous *cough*. But I still see it as worth the risk to support smaller devs such as this when they have something that really appeals to me. If you're not sure then check out youtube, or better yet wait till release and you'll know for sure.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is fantastic.  It boldly goes where no game has gone before: it places you in a crew of 5 other players each having their own responsibilities and when the crew works together you can accomplish almost anything.   That gives you a great sense of achievement both technically and socially that I haven't seen in any other game.  Communication is key so if your the silent type, it's probably not for you.  You HAVE to be engaged with your crew because the ships you crew simply won't function well without it.  The payoff is huge, you really feel like a member of a starship.  Another fantastic element is roleplay and gameplay are one and the same.  Your captain is your leader and speaking to him in true roleplay talk or just plain talk really makes no difference because it's really all the same thing.There's a lot to learn in this game, but not overwhelming.  There's even a manual in the options menu if you need to read up on something.  Most of the game revolves around hanging with your crew as you visit planets and do away missions or space battles where you must fill a role whether it be piloting, managing the power systems, scanning for lifeforms, manning a turret, or what not. Graphics as some have said, are not best of the best, but hardly bad actually I think they are very, very nice with plenty of fancy surface and lighting details.The music has nothing on games like FTL, but again it is very good for it's purpose, and I suspect they will expand the soundtrack a lot more in the future.The community is mostly great.  There are some greifers here and there, I find it's best to say hello when you join is a good way to know what kind of people you are going to play with.It is still early access, but the devs are very active so lots of content pours in frequently.Being EA, the planets you can visit are a bit limited in that you will find yourself visiting the same areas frequently until they add more locations.  However the galaxy map is huge and generated new in every new game and some things such as loot and enemies and backgrounds are generated differently with each planet, plus there's no limit to how many new planets the devs can create.  There's really no limit to the vast amount of possibilities this game has going for it.The community is a bit small right now but there's never a shortage of games you can find to join, just make sure to warm up to the captain for best results. (He is the only one that can kick players)Price is a bit high for EA, but it is a fully multiplayer game and the base game is already very solid.Overall this game is really the experience I've been looking for for a long time: a game where you team up as a crew of players and have endless adventures aboard a totally huge randomly generated galaxy.8.9/10 EA score,  10/10 if they get everything right in the official release.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you ever wanted a game that simulates the experience of a Star Trek bridge look no further. There are space battles, there is boarding, there are away missions, and it is all very fun and addicting; especially if you happen to join a good crew.For those worried about early access: the game is very stable, in 27 hours the only hiccup I've had is one disconnect. There are latency issues to be expected if you are in Europe and connecting to a game on the US west coast, but game breaking bugs are almost entirely non-existent. The game's core elements are completely in place and it does not leave you feeling like major aspects of the game are missing.There is not currently a very high amount of content in the game. After a few planets and a few battles you will definitely get the sense that you have "Been there, done that",  but the rogue-like elements and the ever increasing difficulty of the enemies as your journey goes on will keep you wanting to see what's at the end of your next jump, or whats for sale at the shop over in sector 1751. There are currently a few missions available in the game from NPC's that can give your adventures a sense of purpose, but there is no real story as of the time of this review.The price is definitely the biggest drawback to this game. In its current state it feels like something that would fit the $10-$15 price range. That being said: having made the $25 commitment, I have no regrets. If you are an impatient gamer who wants non-stop action this game is probably not for you. It is intense action followed by periods of discussing plans, or debating which piece of gear to buy next, etc... If you are easily bored this may be a problem.And if you find yourself on a desert world, don't listen to the guy who tells you to follow him out into the sands away from the rest of the crew.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								I tried this game tonight, and had to force my bloodshot eyes to turn away after nearly 6 hours of non stop adventure.  This game is a breath of fresh air, this game is exactly what the space Genre needs.  This game has the foundation of possibly the most accessable, but also DEEP space sim games I have played in decades. I am not going to lie, the game is a bit rough around the edges, the AI, the clunky animations, the tired generic models.  But even this sort of adds to the charm, it gives it a retro quality, and the simplicity of the interfaces make it instantly accessable!At first the ugly nature of the graphics can be unsettling. However it all comes together in just the right way so that your imagination, and your interaction with your friends and the universe around you fills in the gaps, and smoothes the edges.  The game strikes the perfect balance of creating a sandbox with stuff to do, but letting your imagination fill in the gaps.  We picked a stealthy ship.  Thinking - hey, were newb, lets avoid trouble, and attack only when we have the advantage!  It took us a half hour or so to figure out the controls well enough to go to warp and not blow ourselves up.  On the first planet we discovered, We had to wear our space suits to walk around as it was a hot lava planet.  We ran a surface scan, and found 11 life forms.  It took a while but when we found them, it was funny as can be, we had no idea of the aliens would be friendly, or what.  I stood their, pointing my gun at them, asking my engineer for his advice, backing away as these lava slimes appraoched.  they didn't shoot or hurt lava or anything, so I decided to stand my ground. A split second later I was in agony, my health below 40%!  These aren't friendly aliens at all!  Open fire!My engineer dutifully helped me slay all 11 of them, and we went on to explore the rest of the planet and got a few bits of loot for our trouble, including a nice new shield generator. In another instance we spawned in and were attacked by an enemy ship, not an easy little drone like we had gotten used to so far, but a full power ship.  Thinking it would be a pushover, we engaged, the jolly roger unfurled!   Within seconds we learned (the hard way) how important the science officers role could be, as our upgraded and powerful shields vanished in the first volley!  We needed to modulate the shields and hit em with programs!Our ship was on fire!  And so my engineer friend dropped what he was doing and put out the fires. While I modulated the shields and tried to figure out what programs would help.  Whatever I Was doing it helped, the enemy's shots stopped destroying our shields, and our shots started penetrating. The battle was white knuckle, with our systems overheating and exhausted, we lost main engine power, and sat toe to toe trading blows.  When it was over, we won by the skin of our teeth, our ship was below 20% hull, almost no armor left... Our ship was full of holes, and we limped to Sector Zero (the main outpost space station with NPC's you can talk to, to get repairs.  It took me a minute to figure out how to drop the shields to get repaired, but it was nice to be fully repaired and ready to go.  Plus we had some missions to do next time we play!If you have even the slightest bit of love for the captains chair, science officers station, running the guts of a starship, piloting it, or working the guns,  you owe it to yourself to at least give this game a try.  Return it if you don't like it!  I simply cannot believe that this game isn't being watched as closely as it should be. Tonight, I jumped in with a friend, he chose engineer, and I of course had to be captain. From the first moments to the last moments, we were laughing, arguing, cursing, sweating, and cheering. I didn't even mind the lack of a tutorial, figuring out the ship and controls wasn't too steep of a learning curve, indeed, learning to properly configure the AI was the hardest part, and if you play with real people you won't have that issue as much. I would say this game loses a lot of it's charm if you try to play it solo.  I would say play it with 2 people at a minimum the first time you try it, and one should be captain, and one should be pilot.  The captain should run all the stations, while the pilot pilots.  The captain can functionally operate every station, just not as well.  But it's enough that you can have fun and get things done. With a full group, cooperating and having a good attitude, the game is a total utter gem. I can't wait to see the finished product with all the features complete and a universe full of sandbox content to explore... TRY THIS GAME!

Early Access Review
								This is a great first-person starship simulator online. There are five classes. Scientist, weapons specialists, engineer, pilot and captian. When you join a game online you join a new crew each time usually, with new people, and possibly new ship. When you start your own ship, you save it and get a different crew each time when people join. Every part of the crew usually makes the decisions on where to go, what missions to take, what things you need, etc. If you are looking for a little bit of info on what you can do, here it is:Weapons Specialist (WS): You man the weapons in the weapons bay. When on missions you are usually the one with more health and attck from talent points (TP) your crew gets from leveling up. Fighting monsters on planets and shooting and boarding enemy ships is what you do. Scientist: You work in the lab, do all scans, run the shields, do research, and work with programs and viruses. The lab work is done when you stuff random goo and research materials into the 'atomizer' and if gives you research material. When you do research you use those things to give your crew upgrades. When you run the sheilds you set them for physical or energy weapons that you find out about when you scan their ship. When you scan the ship of the A.I. you scan for weapons, components, etc, and it is usuallu important to know your ship's component so you figure out if there is anything you need on the A.I. ship you could get. And with virus and programs you use programs to disable or take things from the enemy ship and stop virusses the enemy ship may puts on you. You also usually get to yell at the engineer to get you fuel capsules.Engineer: You work all the engineering stuff and systems. There are so many systems to explain that it would take me a while and a lot of time to explain it so I am just gonna leave it to: You get to learn a top to know what to press, when to press it, and how things work. There.Pilot: Pretty straightforward. Not much I can say other than the fact that you pilot the ship.Captian: Again, self-explainatory. CAPTIAN.As always there is aton more things to all of these things than I explained and said, and there is so much fun to have testing and learning how to use everything.This is a great game, with real-time voice chat, so it feels like you are actually on a crew. That is a very short overview of Pulsar: Really great game.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								PULSAR: Lost Colony even in early access is already a great investment and feels pretty complete despite some bugs. This is the first time I've ever said that about an early access game and hopefully it won't be the last. There is absolutely no story so I won't be covering that. Gameplay  In a nutshell, imagine what you would do aboard the U.S.S. Enterprise. For those who don't know the ship specifically, imagine what is done onboard  the famous spaceship in Star Trek. You have 5 classes; each with their own upgrades that contribute to other crew members and the ship itself. Captain, scientist, pilot, engineer and gunner. I'll list these off individually to make it easier to take in. Captain The captain chooses what to do, where to go and what to buy. He or she is also the one who gives you a limit on what you can spend as the money you receive goes towards everyone. Scientist The scientist is responsible for buffing and debuffing ships and scanning for enemies and mines both on the ship and on foot. He can also decide whether to sacrifice shields for a more stealthy approach or keep the shields strong. He's basically the 'support' class of the crew. Pilot  The pilot is self explanatory. They're responsible for maneuvering the ship to align with the current and future destinations and help to either engage or retreat from enemy ships. Engineer The engineer is probably the most hectic job of all. As the engineer you're responsible for warp ignition and preparation, keeping the core cool, making sure that the right systems are on and the wrong ones off, repairing damaged systems, turning the shields off and on for ship repairs and making sure to send fuel cores up so that the scientist can continue to use his/her buffs and debuffs to keep the ship from exploding.  Gunner The gunner is the most simple job. Your job is to be ready to shoot at hostiles when given the order or when you've received fire.While some jobs are more complicated than others, every crew member is valuable and that is what I love about this game. If you're only interested in singleplayer then this is not the game for you. The A.I. isn't too bright and will end up getting you killed.  Graphics and Sound Both the graphics and the sound are pretty outdated but once you play you definitely won't care. It's a very innovative and interactive game. The pictures on the store page shows you exactly how it will look.I absolutely recommend this game without a doubt. The community is very friendly and helpful and the adventure no matter if you're starting a new game or helping someone with theirs is always different. I think that the $25 price for an early access game is a bit steep but still worth every penny. If this game is developed further and goes out of early access I have no doubt in my mind that it could end up as one of the greatest and most memorable games ever made. That is how fun this is and how confident I am about it with the direction it's in. This game doesn't require a mic to play but it is strongly recommended as constant communication is key to staying alive in the heat of battle.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								Great game, however performance is quite poor on the big ships, especially on the interior. Overall, the game is great if you enjoy working as a team to defeat enemy space ships, completing missions, and visiting different planets each with new things to discover! This is sort of what No mans sky should've been, even though this games map is a lot smaller, it feels much better as you can actually make meaningful upgrades to your crew, and ship. For example, you can buy nuclear warheads for your weapons expert to launch at enemy vessles, or you can increase your ships coolant capacity or engine power etc. Space combat feels great on this game, and its very satisfying when you and your crew take out a gigantic enemy space ship which attempted to raid you, and loot the remains of their ship! You can sell scrap which you can obtain from enemy ships, and buy new equipment for your own ship instead to become stronger! Your crew is made up of a Captain who is in charge of your ship, a Pilot who pilots your ship at the captains will, a weapons expert who is responsible for maintaining weapons and engaging the enemy, an engineer who is in charge of maintaining the ships health, core temp, power etc. And also a scientist who researches new things which you can find on planets! Each crew member has a very unique, yet important role, and having a whole crew co-operating together and making the ship run feels great, it's honestly a very good co-op experience if done right.The graphics could be a little better, especially the interiors of the ships, however the skybox, and the planets look great! One drawback of this game however, is that sometimes when on the bigger ships, you tend to get around 30-40 FPS on a pretty decent PC like mine, even though I run games like Arma 3 at around 60 FPS. However it's not unplayable, and doesn't ruin the experience for me.The devs do bring out regular updates, and they recently added jetpacks to the game, allowing you to jump multiple times in the air. Positives of the game: Very fun with friends Feels great when you operate such a big ship with your friends Lots of stars/planets to explore Random NPC missions such as exploring lost ships, engaging in combat, etc. Unique roles for each crew member Upgrades to shipsNegatives:  Graphics aren't the best Sometimes performance is a little low

Early Access Review
								I can understand where some of the frustration of the VR haters comes from. I don't fully agree with it, But i understand it. I can understand you putting VR into the game to make it more atractive and thus increasing your sales. Solid tactic. Nothing wrong with that. What i do have a problem with is that the game's biggest flaw at the moment, The lack of content, Is not beeing adressed at all. A couple of new planets and 1 ship in over 1.5 years of development is just not enough. That is a valid point of critique on the developers's end. To add on top of that the AI system STILL does not function. It's basically impossible to play this game single player because in order to run an effective ship, You need to punch in fuel cells manually in order to reload shields, programs etc. This would have been no problem if you could just assign your damm egineering bot to do that for you, allas, That STILL does not work. I know the focus is on multiplayer, But beeing able to play single player every now and again might be fun,. Conclusion is, It's not the fact that VR is beeing put in the game that♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥people of. It's the fact that a lot of promisses are beeing broken in order to focus more on VR desgin. It's another pre alpha game where the developers break there prommise over and over and over. This game might be some day enjoyable, If it get's a massive injection of new content. For now, Don't buy it. Or at least wait till it's on sale

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								An excellent space simulator! I've heard this is in the same vein as Artemis Bridge Simulator. I joined on with a number of friends as the engineer. After about 30-60 minutes, I'd gotten the basics down well enough. It seems that each player has enough to do that all are busy, especially during combat.I absolutely love the tension as you warp into a new sector, with potentially hostile ships - everyone is holding their breath, waiting for the scan to come back with their fingers ready at their battlestations. Exquisite!So far I have only played in a pre-assembled group, so I do not have experience with how jumping into a public game goes. I will say that being in a group with voice chat amplifies the experience greatly. There's something magical about hearing "Weapons are down! Give me weapons!" or "Refill my shield charges ASAP; we're getting hammered!" in the heat of battle. A really fantastically crafted experience.The game provides a really engaging opportunity to run not only your own ship, but various kinds of ships. I would absolutely recommend this game to anyone looking to have a crack at running their own spaceship!For those who'd like to see how the game actually plays, feel free to scope out our misadventures here on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLMZD1JcBH-MIqSwPt6sZztMEjUFf7VdwZor here on steam: http://steamcommunity.com/id/morjax/videos/?appid=252870

content:
Posted: February 6
Early Access Review
								I do not recommend this game based on current amount of content. Some of the most annoying things that I've come across are:-Planets are mostly empty, you run , run, run , radiation -> dead . Not much exploration you can do since you'll probably find only a abandoned/manned station, ship....-If you board a enemy ship you can't do much except destroy/turn off generator so turn off shields and destroy the ship... Destroying life support has no meaning since the AI will keep re-spawning regardless-Most of the systems are completely empty, with nothing to do in it-Enemy AI keeps 'teleporing' ,like it is lagging...you can barely shoot them with a gun... Game was fun only because i played it with a couple of friends. Probably wouldn't have touched it otherwise. 23€ for this amount of content is simply not worth it at this moment. Probably the single interesting mechanic (except being co-op) is being able to provide more energy to shields while cutting life support and stuff like that...

content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								So firstly the Dev's of this game are insanely detected about this.Open-world Space & Planet exploration game, 5 player co-op, you'd think that'd require a huge development team.Nope, not only have the guys at Leafy Dev's done this on their own but they've done it well!Still in Beta and there's already a ton of stories me and my friends are able to share back and fourth about our exploits, which are often made even more special because we experienced this together, and together having to essentialy synchronize as a team, so when we earned something we damn well earned it!If you want a game where you and up to 4 other friends can take a space ship and just explore the Galaxy like they do in Star Trek this is by far the best game that let's you do it in a fun, engaging and memorable way. With five distinct classes of Captain, Weapons, Science, Engineering and Pilot. If you're a space exploration fan, have some friends and want a truly engaging experience this is *the* game in my opinion. The only thing I feel the need to pre-warn is that being in Beta the Dev's are still working out the Balancing of the game, so you might get stages where it seems a bit too easy or (my preference) a bit too hard.Keep up the great work Leafy Devs! :)
