content:
Posted: September 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is one of a kind.  The closest thing I know of is artemis bridge simulator but that is more of a lan rpg.  This is my dream game.  A 5 player co-op first person version of FTL.  I'm surprised it took such a small indie studio to even attempt such a thing and yet it is coming along at a remarkable pace.  I was an original backer and played the game since its barely functioning alpha release February of 2014.  At this point in development there is definitely enough content to have a blast with 4 other friends.  The story and mission content is still forthcoming and furthere changes will likely be made to the existing 5 classes but I would definitely recommend picking this game up if you can convince a few friends to join you.  Pick up groups with randoms can also be fun.  I would only warn against playing alone with bots since the AI is not fully implemented.

Early Access Review
								My friend introduced me to this game months ago and ever since we were waiting for the game's release. I thought that it was a bit expensive at first but with only 4 hours played I can already say it was worth the money. Yes the graphics are meh in todays standards but if you want a fun, exciting exploration game with seemingly endless possibilities, then this is definitely for you. So far I have only played the multiplayer, and I have experienced very little playing with bots, but I know that the co-op in this game is well done, fun and overall amazing. Me and my friends could seemingly play endlessly (which is helpful since we make progress so slowly) and overall I think this is one of the best games i've played all year. I look forward to exploring the universe even more. I strongly urge you to check out some gameplay of this game, and if you're interested ive just uploaded the first video of many in a Pulsar funny moments series. I'd really appreciate if you could leave feedback as this is my first video, but even if you don't, i recommend you watch a vdeo of some kind. My video is extremely edited down however, so I recommend you also watch some full gameplay footage. Thanks and enjoy the game!

content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								Five astronauts! One spaceship. Infinite possibilities?  If you ever wanted to control a spaceship together with 4 other real players, this might be the game for you. The flight controls, engines and subsystems are all operated from computer terminals, located on the bridge and other places inside the ship. Players must coordinate their actions to effectively repel enemies or even jump from one sector to the next. While it's the Captains job to take over this coordination (and drink coffee), the Pilot controls the movement, the Weapon Specialist operates the gun turrents, the Scientist the ships software and scanners and the Engineer watches over the energy usage and temperature of the core.   Gameplay example: If you need your weapons to reload faster, the Engineer can switch of systems like internal lights and air conditioning to reroute more power to the weapons or he may switch of shields to have even more power available. The Scientist can temporally boost certain systems with his programs or he can try to hack the enemy ships systems. Of course you can't use all systems on full power at all times, since your ships core will heat up dangerously. Gameplay is often described as Faster Than Light in 3D and Coop.  You can board enemy ships and fight AI crews, explore planets, loot candy and go shopping in space stations. On your travels you will find scrap to sell or ship parts to instal. It's important to plan a route that passes by repair stations to repair the hull or upgrade with new parts. Also you want to stock up on fuel, missiles and coolant fluid used to cool the core in the heat of battle. At the moment there are 5 ships to choose from, all different in size and layout. They all have beautiful lounges to relax and one even has a bar. 10/10 points for that alone.  In the end of the day it's a very fun coop-experience, you want to share with a group of good friends OR the very nice community.  In future I would love to see more things to do onboard except operation the ship. How about some mini games to pass the idle time (btw: there is no idle time, if you don't want. You can jump into action in less than a minute) or enable Roleplay.

content:
Posted: September 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is amazing! It's a multi palyer crew spaceship sim. Basically what Star citizen is going to be jsut on a lower graphical scale.Currently it's in alpha and feels like it. A good portian of the mechanices are still not implemented and there is no tutorial. The only way to learn how to play and what's in and what's not is to open the menu and click View manual.Basically when you first join the server you pick your role: Captain, Pilot, Scientist, Weapons Specialist and EngineerThe Capt. Pulls all the info from everyone together and tells everyone what to do (this person should know how to play, they should be ableto guide the others) The capt also buys and sell stuff and is more or less in control of the money.The Pilot, moves the ship. To warp he has to line up up the ship and the engineeer has to press a button. The pilot doesn't.The Weapons Sepc. Shoots the gun (and main gun).The scientist has the best job in my opinion. They send viruses to enamy ships, they clean the system of viruses, they scan everything, the look up info on verious stuff and run good programs to boost shields give more thrusters ect.The Engineer has the hardest job and in my opinion the 2nd best job. They have to prep for ward, balance the power core temp, turn the power on and off, and provide a boost to the scientist. You may not THINK thats a lot but when everone else uses there stuff it messes with your temp.There are diffrent parts ofthe ship that can be damaged and needs repaired to keep that part going.It feels a lot like guns of icurus but in space.Like i said before; currently there is a lot missing of the game. but from whats not working, this game is going to be awesome!

Early Access Review
								Mission Log.... uh... One!Inherited a ship from my grandfather, rust bucket called The Long Night.  Took it out for a test jump, ended up in orbit around a green star. Ship seemed allergic to the heat and radiation, oxygen generator decided to have a nap.  Blind jumped to a rock formation for repairs, coaxed the O2 generator into wakefulness, said Hi to a passerby. Passerby seemed allergic to the Long Night, gave gifts of red beams and fireworks, delivery mechanism needed work, as hull got hit, and caved in.  Waiting in line at the Pearly gates for a reincarnation, so no further log entries expected.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								PULSAR is an interesting game, but somewhat lacks originality and is reminiscent of many games in the space/adventure genre. It is a great game to have a laugh with friends and explore new worlds, however the gameplay gets boring quickly due to there being extremely limited goals or missions to complete. Most of these are very bland and offer no unique reward to the player. The different ships available are detailed both graphically and functionally, and this game really brings a new meaning to teamwork, as the ship systems require a near-full crew to operate efficiently. The concept of the game is fun, but is unlikely to be a game that you will come back to later down the line. The planets aren't particularly detailed and lack in many areas, including map size and places of interest.Overall, I rate PULSAR: Lost Colony a 6/10 due to the bland characteristics, but enjoyable gameplay with friends.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								Five people on a spaceship try not to explode.You've got the Captain, who tells everyone what to do so nothing explodes. Little effort required.There's the Scientist, who does research and manages programs and scanning so nothing explodes. Their systems are a little complex, so a little effort required.The Engineer micromanages systems, warping, and most technical stuff in a fruitless effort to make nothing explode. Their systems are relatively complicated as you have to respond to captains' orders as well as making sure  everyone else has power. Hard.The Pilot is in charge of unsuccessfully dodging attacks and responding to countless requests of "Align ship to jump!" Easy once you learn the controls. Can't do much to not explode.Last and kinda least, the Combat Specialist is in charge of manning guns and other weapons. Aim, shoot, and hope you don't die. Relatively easy. Shoot the things that are making you explode.11/10 would completely fail to not explode again.

content:
Posted: January 1
Early Access Review
								So buggy this shouldn't of been released, even in early access.  The game is built for a respawning system, but it doesn't work.  If you die, it's just straight up game over, you never come back.  This is frustrating because enemies move like they're flash on cocaine, and you have a single fire pistol with like one shot per 20 seconds fire rate, but enemies will rapid fire you down with pinpoint accuracy instantly.And while the space combat is fun, it's annoying as hell that LITERALLY EVERYTHING THAT ISN'T YOUR FACTION IS HOSTILE TO YOU.  There's no such thing as neutral, or civillians, or what have you.  As soon as you're in range, everything that spots you will fire upon you. AND THEN YOU LOSE REPUTATION WITH THEM EVEN IF YOU DON'T DO ANYTHING.  It's ♥♥♥♥ing straight ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.

content:
Posted: April 19
Early Access Review
								I'm on the edge with this game. Personally, I believe this game is amazing. It's very fun and immersive, you seldom feel useless in your crew of 5.The problem I have with this game is how it lacks any goal. The main quest is currently in development so there's not much going on there.The quests you have currently are mostly all the same (They're definitely not the main attraction of the game). You find yourself saying "I guess I'll just go there" instead of going somewhere because you're certain that's where you want to go. You're just left wandering this empty space for long periods of time, hoping for something to do.PULSAR has a massive lack of content right now. Yes; Each individual job you can do on your ship is incredibly fun, and you can spend hours at a time on any single job (I prefer the scientist position),  but as a game in general, there is actually not a lot to do. If you want to have a lot of fun here, expect it to mostly be roleplay - And by that I mean, fake player-made goals.All in all, I don't think this game is worth your money. Yet. When (or if) more content is added, definitely pick this up. However just leave it for now.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								EDITCheck comments and you'll see almost everything I listed here was simply due to the lack of easily accesible documentation.Most of the features are actually present just not documented in an obvious way (like in the controls).Read the following if you'd like, but take it with a grain of salt.----------------------------------PLEASE NOTEI did not play this game for very long (3 hours), but these were my first impressionsI don't recommend this game for the price (biggest issue) in its current state.This game, in my opinion, is worth at most five dollars.I got this game with a friend on sale for about $15 USDThe same day I requested a refund.The major issue is the price, the game is simply not worth $24 USD.I can't convince my friends to buy a game for $24 USD I'm not even sure I like to buy it and play.Pros - cool concept - interesting co opCons - overpriced (biggest issue; if this game was a couple bucks it'd definitely be worth it) - no official documentation on what to do at the start of the game (and for many other things) - planet surfaces are ugly and boring (sure it's part of the art style, but the planets look like Turok with semi-HD textures) - you have to teleport onto planets, ships, and stations (no docking, which would be awesome, and no landers) - very slow gameplay - not very fun if you don't have 5 friends to play this - can't invite friends to your server through steam (you have to scroll through the server browser, which has no search) - no jumping/vaulting or crouching (feels very awkward as you are always grounded)Overall, this game isn't for everyone, and definitely not worth $24 USD

number of helpful: 4 of 14 people (29%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								I love star trek.  I live for science fiction.  I used to play a game with my friends called "what's the worst thing you would do to go to space".  "I would eat a bowl of♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; was the very first answer, and I currently have 2nd place for "eat a plate of my mother's refrigerated pubes".I played thousands of hours of Star Trek: Bridge Commander.  I convinced all my friends to play Artemis and we played it as much as the game's awful interface would allow.  This game is about as good as I could've ever imagine Artemis could be with mods about 6 years ago.The potatoes are finished and onto the meat:  PROS:+ There's a universe to explore+ There's a learning curve to exploring it that feels "just right". + Playing with your friends and training to be a well-oiled crew is easily some of the most fun I've ever had playing videogamesCONS:- The graphics are bad.  It is ugly.  You won't like looking at anything but space.- LOTS of content missing.  If you've ever wondered what half a game feels like, this is it.- The current system of ship capturing and respawning is half-baked at best.  It's hard to immerse yourself when the key to success is a highly exploitable metagameSUMMARY:In its current state, I cannot recommend PULSAR: Lost Colony despite it being the #1 game on my watchlist for over a year.  The game is as barely functional as an early access game can barely be.  It is my hope that the development team doesn't take the current level of sales as a success and move onto other projects, leaving PULSAR in the state of development hell that the rest of us know early access titles to be.  It is my hope that this is just the beginning of a long voyage full of setbacks and the lessons we learn from them, culminating in a fruitful return, just like a great episode of Star Trek :)

number of helpful: 17 of 42 people (40%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								Not as cool as I was hoping for it to be.  I don't believe it should be worth $25, even for a gracious "feed the devs" cost.  Shoddily made enemy AI and shoddily made friendly AI, clunky interactions and of course, low amount of content.  Every location you see in the trailer is in actuality every location in the game, and every planet is the same as it would be in another playthrough.  The only real charm they expect you to experience is playing the game with your friends.  With your friends.  Meaning you and your buddies fork over $25 for a total $125, since they don't like the idea of the 5-pack for 4-copies deal, and they haven't put it on sale at all.  Even then, it'd still be $100, if you try to buy the 5pack!  Overall I'd say not worth the money they're asking, and that's why the overall reviews count reflects the dwindling playerbase reflects the cost shows the devs haven't sold this product enough.How would I have done it?  Well it's pretty bold but here's how it goes.  You can buy the game for $20, right, and play it as much as you want whenever you want.  BUT, you can also purchase 8 hours of game time for yourself or someone else at $5, starting when they launch it on steam, ending when the timer runs out.  It doesn't tick while the game isn't on.  As such, if you have that one friend with the loaded wallet, he/she can give up a whole $25 to assemble friends to play this game.  In the true reality, nobody should play this game more than twice, once to learn how to fail and once to learn how to win.  Any more and you'll see through the sham that is this game's minute content pool.  Additionally, if you have that group of your pals, you won't be playing this game all the time like "oh let's pop into some PULSAR right quick".  This is a one time game, and deserves a less binding price model.  And then to top it all off I'd reduce the price to $12.49 when the summer sale rolls along so I don't lose business, because I've got two orbs between my legs and a brain under the dome.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								Deceptive trailer. Buggy, repetitive and shallow gameplay.Like flying ships? Ship flying is terrible, clunky, slow and there is literally nothing in space. Nothing.Like exploring planets? The planets are smaller than your backyard, and there is nothing on a planet. Nothing.Like shooting? Worst shooting gameplay ever, there's Doom clones from 1995 that are better, and I'm not joking, it's straight up the worst♥♥♥♥♥♥ever.Like managing a ship? There's a couple on/off switches and that't about it, it might give you the impression that the panels are complex, but they're not, they just look cool on face value but once you get in the game there's like 3 buttons you can click and trust me when I say that after pressing them twice you don't feel like repeating it.This game is extremely shallow and overpriced. Don't buy this unless it's 3 dollars/euros. This should have been a free game, and I hope more negative reviews roll in because frankly I'm appalled at how all these 3 hours game time reviewers are giving good reviews for absolutely one of the most boring games.You're warned, this game is absolutely not worth money, it should be free for the hobby project it really is. Disgusting greedy kid who charges for this. Go home. Take my money and donate it to some charity because you have no shame or dignity for charging people.

number of helpful: 2 of 14 people (14%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game has SO much potential, and is one of the first games I've come across that has a true co-op feel that is a good mix between Firefly meets space combat game.However, the new update has completely broken what is already challenging gameplay, even for the the most experienced of space sim pilots. The AI bots are now more useless than ever, and running into even the basic of battles means almost always certain death. You rarely get a chance to level anything on the ship now, and if you do the permadeath model means you're back to square one if you happen randomly into the wrong sector.Until the devs do a basic re-tweak of simple gameplay mechanics this game is not worth the Early Access dollars.

I do not regret my purchase.Here is my abridged oppinion of the game:It is good over all and development is steadily improving the game.Im a big fan of the artistic style, music, and the teamwork/exploration oriented gameplay.The community behind the game is also rather friendly and welcoming.My only big complaint is that there is no ability to make the player-character jump. (at least the last time I checked that is), instead you will require a jetpack which for some reason is only available on one of the ship classes, which limits the exploration you can do if you do not choose said ship.My other complaint is that Foxxy is no longer to be found anywhere. :cI keep coming back to this game after leaving it for several months. And every time I do I am pleasantly surprised by the new content.The crew AI is not very smart, and not easy to command either; however the last time I played they improved significantly and I expect them to get better in the future.Sadly I've yet to have the chance to play this game to the fullest as I've never had all 4 of my friends online and willing at the same time to play with. That one is on me however.Required perhipherals to play this game properly:More friends with the game than I have.A Discord server or simmilar and associated pehripherals (mics for everyone, etc.)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								The game that would result in someone getting FTL and Guns of Icarus into a bed together would be glorious.  Luckily, Leafy Games did it, and the result is glorious.  You can take control as one of five classes: Captain, Pilot, Scientist, Engineer, and Weapons Specialist.  Each one has their own upgradable abilites that help them along their journey.  Each class is also extremely fun.  Even the Scientist, who does nothing but scan ships and deploy viruses, is an intense and satisfying class.Along with fun classes are the fun scenarios.  From battling ancient sentries to bringing someone a lost sandwhich, each scenario and quest is fun.  Each scenario is also very balanced.  The bosses feel hard, but will never induce rage.  Sentry drones are easy to take out, but they are more than a mere nuisance.  You will never get bored playing this game.Possibly the best part of the game is the community.  While their are some less than mature people playing (there have been ships named the H.M.S.♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you will always be greeted by friendly space trekkers willing to help you when they can.  This is the type of game where friendships are made.All in all, this is one of the best games I've played, even though it's in Early Access.The worst part about the game are the few bugs that will most certainly be fixed in the next update.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								Review is written during beta 4.2 NOV 2015Pros: Has classic space combat mechanics; Your weapons fire when the angle is appropriate and is charged and you have one shield that covers the entire ship. You also have a quantum shield that prevents the enemy from teleporting to your ship. The player(s) have to manage the energy distribution, control the amount of heat in the reactor to prevent a system failure, and use programs to debuff the enemy or remove debuffs.Cons: Default Unity shaders. Lacks quest; Classic fetch quest. Limited variety of firearms, they are all pistols. Limited vareity of components, each component has only 0-5 variants with only the level scaling up. Limited amount of opponents; You get to fight 5 special enemy ships and then the default ships. The AI is just godly stupid, it cannot tell when there is a wall between them and will try to shoot through walls. Everytime you load a gamesave, you have to respend your talent points and AI priority. Invisible items that show up on radar but you cannot see; And yes, I'm on the right floor. Alot of the planets just use the same map. Apparently, every ship uses the same computer architecture because viruses work on all of them; Even the infected.I wanted to stay neutral but Steam made me choose.

Early Access Review
								I only have a few hours under my belt, but I like what I've seen so far.Interesting game concept, designed around teamwork. Each player having their own role to perform makes everyone feel useful, to an extent. Some jobs require more attention than others, such as pilot or engineer. Obviously the game needs more content, but it is still early access, so it will come. One thing I WOULD like to see implemented though, is some sort of a job queueing system. Some players will obviously be more comfortable doing a certain role (I've only been a Scientist so far) And joining games is rolling the dice, because you're probably not going to end up in the role you would like, which can make it more difficult to gel with a new team. So it would be nice if there was a way to queue as a scientist, or pilot etc, and be shown a list of games where that role is needed.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								Years ago I dreamed up a nice little concept for a game. A difficult co-op sci-fi FTL-like FPS. Fast forward a while and this game pops out of nowhere. I played the game on my own with bots and had a fun time, but I was waiting to write a review until I'd played the multiplayer with friends, since the game IS all about cooperation and teamwork and that bullocks.When I eventually did play with a friend, we had so much fun getting blown up or turned into swiss cheese by enemy crews. What's even better is that that was before we even discovered you could explore planets!-PROS--A completely cooperative game, no competitive modes. This might be a con for some people, I don't mind it though.-A vast, dangerous galaxy to explore with six different factions (Not including the Infection)-Missions, albeit not randomly generated ones, that can sometimes end up being more of an adventure than you originally expected.-Procedurally generated planets with different hazards, such as an acidic atmosphere, or a lack of oxygen.-Multiple ships to choose from with different interiors, layouts, and specs.-CONS--The planets are sometimes disappointingly small, and can be glitchy. It IS early access however, so what did you expect?-It isn't exactly overflowing with content. It is still VERY entertaining, even if you're only playing with one other person, so it makes up for it.-While I don't mind the clean, almost cell shaded look of the equipment and ships-- Infact I think some of the planets I've seen have even made me go "That's really pretty!"-- But the people look hideous. They're like tall, chubby space-dwarves.All in all, I'd recommend this game if you have friends, and even if you don't. You're missing out if you don't at least play on a public game. Careful though, I hear there's the rare troll that comes around and screws you and your crew over.-Things I, and many other people, would like to see in the future--Diplomacy! I'm sure they already have this planned in the future, what with the inclusion of a comms tab, but it still needs to be said (For the billionth time). Perhaps even a special talent for the captain that gives a bonus to diplomacy checks?-Larger ships. More vessels like the very popular Roland. Large and spacey, yet somewhat homely.-More of a variety of alien lifeforms. Fun things that can pose an actual threat in the long run, something like the creatures in the Thing, or some sort of Xenomorph-like alien parasite (If you've played the game, you thought about that at least once while holding a scanner).-Higher 'Level' planets. Planets that would be too inhospitibal for the average exosuit, requiring special upgrades to the suits.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								We arrive at the Citadel, a broken thing I call home, skeleton crew staffed to conduct extrasolar missions for our federation, retrieving and eliminating mostly. We hunt fugitives, set a mapped path, travel through star systems, asteroids, and planets. Bumping hulls with mass relays, xeno-bio ships, drones and enemy factions. Our mission? To retrieve lost medical supplies, save scientists and possibly encounter hostile space vessels. This is Pulsar, a game about adventures in space, where the game is buggy (read: indev alpha) but updates are plenty, and features more fulfilling than any game that you will find in this specific category of coop star-(word) film simulator. It's got an unexplainable charm of how close it mimics the star-(worded) films, it's not an exact copy of a specific one and it doesn't intend to be, but the exploration feels like star-trek TNG to me (small crew and warp drives). Every player has a role in a crew of five, some interact more with the ingame hologram HUD(s), unifying controls for managing the ship together, but separated only by distance from each role's cubicles.The captains, Dungeon Master… err, Creative Director, for the non-DnD nerds. He/she makes or breaks the adventure because of currency distribution, ship upgrades and mapped missions are all done by this role, directly impacting all other players’ experiences. The weapons specialist, novice of left mouse buttons, and experienced to QTEs (Quick Time Events), where the shot for the missile must be struck by beam weapons first to lower their shield, so the next immediate hit can directly impact their hull, bypassing their shield regeneration. The scientist is a part time script-kitty, medic, away-team lead, and first-strike team point-man. Scientists have the most utility aside from the captain.The engineer, an expert in duct-tape usage and juggling, must allocate the ship's power at its best or worse conditions, or we all explode and die.And the pilot, must dodge missiles, maneuver to mitigate damage in combat, belly up = bad, belly down = good.Best experienced with VOIP, intoxicants, video recording program, and popcorn.

content:

Early Access Review
								If you like the idea of things like Artemis Bridge Simulator this is worth a go. Online play is a lot of fun. The community is small but I haven't had a problem finding a friendly crew whenever I've looked. It feels like a very good game if you have a small group of friends that like to play games together.+Several ships to start with or capture (each with a unique internal setup)+Plenty of ship upgrades to loot or buy and configure your ship to your liking+Large map offers enough space to explore and have an extended adventure+Ship to ship combat feels very good and involves all roles+boarding enemy ships is very cool feature+-Crew Bots are okay enough to play solo till you get a feel for the game, but need work to allow much more-FPS combat feels barebones and not satisfying at the moment, but it works-Planet maps (I've seen so far) are rather small and empty feeling-Game is yet to be optimized, so performance issues at higher video settings were very noticableI put this with Early Access games that are complete enough to be worth playing now even if further development is slow/doesn't happen (though I hope it does). This game fits a uique enough niche that I can overlook it's few flaws.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								Pulsar is unlike any other co-op game I've ever played, since everyone's experience is their own.I learned how to play Engineer first just in case I wanted to kill my crew for the heck of it.I joined a crew that was seemingly a tiny bit dysfunctional. Decided "hey, Im gonna screw these guys over"Acting normal and such when I hear burning. Go to investigate. Entire life support room is on fire. I think nothing of it and put it out and repair the system.Keep plotting to kill crew until I be good guy again when the core is on fire. Think nothing of it since we just got out of combat.Another system catches on fire. Go to put it out. See our ten-year-old weapons officer walk away from the fire. Get suspicious. Tell no one.Going on our merry way when suddenly ship power goes out. Go to reboot system. Weapons officer is responsible. Captain was right about suspicions. Decide to not screw over crew.Later, I'm learning how to be capitan on my own ship, the Damrey.Sceince guy with no mic joins and is probably a noob, and is acting overly cheery.Going along when power goes out. Engie reboots it.Noob science is obvious culprit when he turns it off again and runs to captain's chair when we all go investigate.Tell science if he wants to get kicked he should do it again. He does it again.After this crew I got a drunk pilot and a weapons officer who played edgy music through his mic.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								So... Another early access.People have described this by using references to other games, but I think that's unfair. It is a game in it's own right, I'll try to explain what it's about. If anything, playing this game feels like watching episodes of Star trek TOS and those types of references are readily used by players. Be my redshirt for a day.You play as one out of five crewmen, each have their own class with unique talents (skills) that can be leveled up. The crew share level, which is a nice feature and works well for this co op game. You start of with an under powered ship, warp around to different sectors to engage enemies, navigate minefields, send away teams to planets and just do that whole trek thing. You can also get missions from NPC's on outposts.So, if you like these things, maybe this is for you. I say maybe, because we are currently at beta 3 and the game is severily lacking in game content: the planets have very limited areas, model animations are missing, loads of enemies and locations missing and so on. There's not a whole lot to do yet.That said, I like the premise and the game mechanics presented so far. The development team, although small, find the time to reply to forum posts (even on Steam!), fix issues and consider suggestions. If AAA-studios had HALF the customer service these guys do the gaming industry would be SO much better. If you are tired of buying early access games that are broken, has no dev communication and take forever to get updates, you might actually find that Leafy games is a fresh breath of air.It's Unity 5, so it works pretty well on Linux. There are some optimization issues, but this early in development one cannot expect optimized graphics. In spite of being part of the Unity ghetto, Leafy games showcases that Unity games doesn't have to be unstable, GPU slaughtering beasts of C# nonsense. In particular on the Linuxes!EDIT: there is one feature missing that everyone has been talking about, it is also probably the hardest thing to do. Right now it has network multiplayer, but only for up to 5 people of the crew and only one player ship per server. If we could get multiple player controller ships on the same server it would be amazing!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you've played Faster Than Light (FTL), then you MAY enjoy PULSAR.This game should be played with at least one or two other people.  You start off picking a ship.  After that the host (I think) has to choose Captain out of the 5 classes.  The captain can bring up the map, chart a course through the large and extensive universe.  The ship itself has shields, which protect the hull until the shields take enough damage for the enemy ships to deal damage to your hull, which once the hull reaches zero, your ship explodes and either you reload, or start a new ship.  Each class has a station, or their own in-game computer screen that you stand at.  There are many rooms in the ship, and each of the ship's systems are connected to the 4 main systems.  Science, Engineering, Weapons, Life Support.  Those are the 4 systems you must protect.  If they get damaged enough, a fire starts in the room that you have to put out with extinguishers, then repair the system before the fire starts again.There are missions that you can complete which give you credits and fame.  I spend the credits on replacing ship systems with better ones from repair stations located sparingly throughout the solar system.There are factions.  The infested I have never had the pleasure of meeting but I have heard of them.  Some sort of alien race that create organic or living ships.  There are other neutral or hostile factions I have either not met or have had nothing to do with as of yet.  If you play with a group of friends, you WILL have fun with this game.  Play alone, and it gets rather boring.  The UI could use some work, and more game content would be welcome.  Controller support needs to improve, which it has, but I feel like more customization should be had.  I tried using all the buttons on my xbox 360 controller and I was unable to use the bumpers, which isn't that big a deal.  I play the game mostly with mouse and keyboard unless I'm flying the ship.I would rate this game 9/10.  It's in BETA now so when they fully finish this game, it will be awesome - and it's already really fun.  They plan to come out with much more, such as crafting items and more talents for each class.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								So... Another early access.People have described this by using references to other games, but I think that's unfair. It is a game in it's own right, I'll try to explain what it's about. If anything, playing this game feels like watching episodes of Star trek TOS and those types of references are readily used by players. Be my redshirt for a day.You play as one out of five crewmen, each have their own class with unique talents (skills) that can be leveled up. The crew share level, which is a nice feature and works well for this co op game. You start of with an under powered ship, warp around to different sectors to engage enemies, navigate minefields, send away teams to planets and just do that whole trek thing. You can also get missions from NPC's on outposts.So, if you like these things, maybe this is for you. I say maybe, because we are currently at beta 3 and the game is severily lacking in game content: the planets have very limited areas, model animations are missing, loads of enemies and locations missing and so on. There's not a whole lot to do yet.That said, I like the premise and the game mechanics presented so far. The development team, although small, find the time to reply to forum posts (even on Steam!), fix issues and consider suggestions. If AAA-studios had HALF the customer service these guys do the gaming industry would be SO much better. If you are tired of buying early access games that are broken, has no dev communication and take forever to get updates, you might actually find that Leafy games is a fresh breath of air.It's Unity 5, so it works pretty well on Linux. There are some optimization issues, but this early in development one cannot expect optimized graphics. In spite of being part of the Unity ghetto, Leafy games showcases that Unity games doesn't have to be unstable, GPU slaughtering beasts of C# nonsense. In particular on the Linuxes!EDIT: there is one feature missing that everyone has been talking about, it is also probably the hardest thing to do. Right now it has network multiplayer, but only for up to 5 people of the crew and only one player ship per server. If we could get multiple player controller ships on the same server it would be amazing!

content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is on the right track, trying to capture the experience of being at the helm as a Captain or one of the other 4 roles (engineer, weapons officer, scientist, pilot) however I feel it came out half-baked and that the devs should have waited a bit longer.Before I begin, take note that I do not care if your game is early access, alpha, beta, testing phase. As soon as you open the door to recieve money, you are gonna get reviewed properly, no cookie points for releasing unfinished games! This has become bad practice...I will start with what I feel was "the bad" in my opinion:- The game's single player doesn't really exist. (AI is too troublesome to micro manage) Joining other players with random people invites alot of trolling and incompetant Captains.- The AI is awful and has odd behaviors, for example, teleporting in combat, unable to perform duties properly when set,get stuck all over the place in the ship if they do try to move around in a fight.- The first person shooter portion is bad, hit boxes  are small, don't try to go for limbs or headshots, keep all shots in the center of the target. (otherwise just very basic point and click)- Game already has people cheating, joined one with a Captain who was giving himself credits to buy the best upgrades."The good" luckily, is REALLY good and is keeping this game afloat and on people's radar.- Playing this game with friends on Comms is very rewarding, especially if you roleplay it out a bit.- This is a niche game and will shine a light on a genre that has alot of potential to be done right- The ship's are the star of this show with tons of functionality! Controlling power to weapons, shields, and various departments, all while controlling your coolant to keep your core under control, issuing orders to your crew or blasting the enemy with your all powerful main cannons and even nukes!- Ability to board and sabotage the enemy vessels from the inside and take over the ship for your own.- Going planetside to explore and complete various missions (all though the planets need alot of work, but it does help to have them rather then not have them at all).My score: 6 / 10 - Recommended, however I would wait for a sale or really think about who you can play this with. You can get your moneys worth if you got friends who are really into it and might play it for a week or so, then patiently see if the devs are gonna add more.Just like many early access games, this has ALOT of potential, however I find myself saying that alot, only to be disapointed, so I hope this game can pull it together and make something truely authentic to its genre! Hope this helps you with your decision! I made a video below for my review if you want to see more! 


YouTube™ Video: PULSAR: Lost Colony Review 

			Views: 3,361		

			JC.exe reviews PULSAR: Lost Colony by Leafy Games. Will this game beam you up or just drop out of orbit?		

Things I hope to see:- custom things to add around the ship and interact with (they have stoves, lockers, beds, lights)- The devs already expressed no PvP content, but I still have my hopes they reconsider.- Better random encounters, all AI just wanna fight you.- Something to roleplay out a interaction with enemy pirates, a screen to pull up and hail each other would be EPIC.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								Years ago I dreamed up a nice little concept for a game. A difficult co-op sci-fi FTL-like FPS. Fast forward a while and this game pops out of nowhere. I played the game on my own with bots and had a fun time, but I was waiting to write a review until I'd played the multiplayer with friends, since the game IS all about cooperation and teamwork and that bullocks.When I eventually did play with a friend, we had so much fun getting blown up or turned into swiss cheese by enemy crews. What's even better is that that was before we even discovered you could explore planets!-PROS--A completely cooperative game, no competitive modes. This might be a con for some people, I don't mind it though.-A vast, dangerous galaxy to explore with six different factions (Not including the Infection)-Missions, albeit not randomly generated ones, that can sometimes end up being more of an adventure than you originally expected.-Procedurally generated planets with different hazards, such as an acidic atmosphere, or a lack of oxygen.-Multiple ships to choose from with different interiors, layouts, and specs.-CONS--The planets are sometimes disappointingly small, and can be glitchy. It IS early access however, so what did you expect?-It isn't exactly overflowing with content. It is still VERY entertaining, even if you're only playing with one other person, so it makes up for it.-While I don't mind the clean, almost cell shaded look of the equipment and ships-- Infact I think some of the planets I've seen have even made me go "That's really pretty!"-- But the people look hideous. They're like tall, chubby space-dwarves.All in all, I'd recommend this game if you have friends, and even if you don't. You're missing out if you don't at least play on a public game. Careful though, I hear there's the rare troll that comes around and screws you and your crew over.-Things I, and many other people, would like to see in the future--Diplomacy! I'm sure they already have this planned in the future, what with the inclusion of a comms tab, but it still needs to be said (For the billionth time). Perhaps even a special talent for the captain that gives a bonus to diplomacy checks?-Larger ships. More vessels like the very popular Roland. Large and spacey, yet somewhat homely.-More of a variety of alien lifeforms. Fun things that can pose an actual threat in the long run, something like the creatures in the Thing, or some sort of Xenomorph-like alien parasite (If you've played the game, you thought about that at least once while holding a scanner).-Higher 'Level' planets. Planets that would be too inhospitibal for the average exosuit, requiring special upgrades to the suits.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								Review is written during beta 4.2 NOV 2015Pros: Has classic space combat mechanics; Your weapons fire when the angle is appropriate and is charged and you have one shield that covers the entire ship. You also have a quantum shield that prevents the enemy from teleporting to your ship. The player(s) have to manage the energy distribution, control the amount of heat in the reactor to prevent a system failure, and use programs to debuff the enemy or remove debuffs.Cons: Default Unity shaders. Lacks quest; Classic fetch quest. Limited variety of firearms, they are all pistols. Limited vareity of components, each component has only 0-5 variants with only the level scaling up. Limited amount of opponents; You get to fight 5 special enemy ships and then the default ships. The AI is just godly stupid, it cannot tell when there is a wall between them and will try to shoot through walls. Everytime you load a gamesave, you have to respend your talent points and AI priority. Invisible items that show up on radar but you cannot see; And yes, I'm on the right floor. Alot of the planets just use the same map. Apparently, every ship uses the same computer architecture because viruses work on all of them; Even the infected.I wanted to stay neutral but Steam made me choose.

Early Access Review
								This is a very enjoyable team game.It's ambitious in scope and the concept is excellent. The execution of the concept is also of a very high standard. I went on with a friend and we were joined by another guy where we happily spent about 8 hours straight in this game. Character, crew and ship progression are all in good order and the overall gameplay is solid. The environments are good and seem reasonably varied. My friend and I have talked about wanting a game like this for years now and are happy to see that this one is ticking many boxes.A very high standard of an Early Access title and one that other Early Access developers would do well to measure their own projects by.I would happily advise people to buy this game or at least keep it on your wishlist and track it's progress. It's a great concept, well excuted.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								Read the game's description to find out what this game is about.There is enough content to legitimately play this game but it will run out quickly. The developers have written they plan on adding a lot more content once they have finished the basic game structure.The ship roles need a little bit of work. (E.g. The captain can actually become virtually useless, since he is the one with the least information out of all the crew members at his disposal) I can forgive this since the game still isn't fully fleshed out. The only roles I believe to be ~"feature complete"~ are the pilot and the engineer.Personal combat is kind of terrible. There's little to it. Click to fire your weapon, but enemies will also be firing their weapons instantaneously. If you've played Sven Co-op (Half-Life Mod) this is the best description of how the combat plays out. It is mostly shooting, dying, and coming back to finish them off.Do not buy this game to play with people you do not know.If you (and your friends) can overlook the above points, this game is worth purchasing!

content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've downloaded this game first via some strange ways (also know as not-very-legal-versions). I wanted to try before buy, because I've problems with horror/suspense games (I was afraid this game was, but isn't not!).Imagine Star Trek, without the Hollywood things. This is PULSAR. You can control your own ship, have friends or meet someone to help with your ship, land in planets to explore or complete missions (now you can research things from items you find in the planet).PROS:- The game is really fun.- The graphic is not heavy but it's cool.- The game dynamic is amazing, a lot of things to do, etc.- Is a randomly-generated universe.- A lot of people are noobie-friendly. Is not like the majority of multiplayer games who don't care about the newbies. I like it, since I'm always a newbie!CONS:- A mini-map inside a ship, like the carrier, will be great (really - it's huge and I usually get lost).- It's in beta, so: bugs.- There is a little big of lag.- It would be great to have more team in the ship (up to 10 probably? Specially for ships with more than 1 gun).- Some ships are extremely DARK. - Some people are bad and will damage your ship just because they can and nobody will know who the person was, except if caught in the act. A log system for the captain will be great.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								With the right friends, this game really does seem like your own personal episode of Firefly or Star Trek.  So, here's my take on this game.The Captain ordered us to look for security drones.  We spent about 30 minutes on a search and destroy until we needed to head back and repair the hull.  I am the pilot and yes, I'm a girl.  My first attempt at docking with the repair station was ...sporty.  If you've ever seen the movie galaxy quest then you will have a good idea of what it's like to fit the destroyer into a repair station docking bay.  Our first away mission resulted in our captain yelling "Oh sh*t!" and then promptly dying.  When asked what killed him, he said something "Ambiguous" and told us to head right when we exited the terraforming station.  I headed right and immediately died by the "Ambiguous" hostile who seemed intent on shoving a plasma cannon up my posterior.  I was very happy that someone had remembered to turn on the respawning platform on board the ship.  Except for the need to change my uniform, I was ready to beam back to the planet surface and return the favor.  This game is all about friends and teamwork.  The better your team, the more fun you will have.  I wasn't happy with the price tag considering the state it's currently in but if you play this with a group of people who have a good sense of humor and a love for space operas, you will never regret the purchase.  I love this game and I see only good things to come because it's only going to get better from here.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have only played this game once so far, but this particular session lasted around 2 hours.The game is by far the most immersive one I have ever played. Whichever class you choose, you "hop into" it very quickly. As a weapons specialist, I found myself almost subconsciously relaying targetting info, turret charge, misle lock on progress et cetera to other crew members just after first few minutes of manning the post. Same went for other people, they were reclutant at first but later, especially while in combat, the voice chat resembled what you can hear in any kind of movie or game involving spaceship fights.The game could use some polishing here and there, and of course more content, but overall it's really good. Even better if you ever dreamed to play as a part of spaceship crew.Pros : -Immersion.-Every station is straight-forward, you can get a grasp of your role really quickly.-Every screen is interactive, and you perform your tasks through them - it increases the immersion further.Cons : -The animations feel... clunky at times. I understand those are probably engine limited though.-Some of the enemies lack visual indication of their attacks so you could possibly dodge them or at least see that you're getting hit (magma slugs ._.), and in my opinion they're way too strong.

content:
Posted: March 29
Early Access Review
								This game was incredibly fun when I first got it. It feels like the most complete promise on a 'Star Trek' game that has ever been made. Get together with 4 friends, each of you assume a position of an officer on your own starship: Captain, Pilot, Tactical Officer, Science Officer, and Engineer and go explore the galaxy. Each of these positions feels fun, accurate, and well put together. It's absolutely fantastic. Over and over again the community said, "man this game would be awesome in VR." So the devs released it in VR as a free update, and it is. I can't recommend this game enough. Tl;Dr: The best Star Trek game that's ever been made doesn't have the Star Trek IP.

								This fulfills my need for Star CitizenImagine Star Trek, Elite Dangerous and Firefly had a dangerous unprotected orgy and both Star Trek and Firefly came inside Elite Dangerous and 9 months later there is a baby. The baby grows up to look simple, but has the personality traits of his parents he never knew. Early Access Review
								Fantastic game, but needs more types of missions and a lot of polish. Diplomacy, escort, aid, scouting, and anomaly investigation missions would keep things spiced up. Engineer could possibly have some kind of mini-game dealing with coolant and power routing. Scientist could have more control over atmospherics in the ship, more in-depth shield modulating, and help with translating comms. Captain's chairs should have direct and immediate access to all ship information. UIs could be greatly improved. Perhaps add another shiphand for security vs boarding as well as another hand on the guns. AI is just awful. Bots are nearly worthless and the control scheme set up for them is tedious to refine to get them to work correctly. Otherwise, it's going in a fantastic direction and I highly reccomend it. It has a very good value vs time.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								If you enjoy good co-operative gameplay and aren't obsessed with cutting-edge graphics, this game might just be your thing. I was quite disappointed when the developers of Star Trek Online said they'd cut multi-crewed ships from the feature list...thankfully Pulsar: Lost Colony delivers where STO dropped the ball. The developers at Leafy Games have figured out *exactly* the game I've always wanted to play: Star Trek meets Artemis meets FTL meets Skyrim in space. The sheer amount of detail they've squeezed into this (still work-in-progress) game is pretty astonishing. For example, in a recent nail-biter space battle I cut power to most of the ship's systems to help our reactor to cool down. After we miraculously survived, we noticed our graphics had all gone grayscale...I'd forgotten to restore power to life support and we were slowly suffocating. :) This game is full of little touches like that.Don't let the simple graphics fool you, there's real depth in this gameplay. When I play, I feel I'm living a Star Trek episode. When things go pear-shaped in a battle (such as having to deal with a ship overheat AND boarders beaming in), it can get extremely exciting.While this game isn't finished, what's there is really fun. It lacks a tutorial but there is an in-game manual which you can also find on the company's website. If you don't mind figuring stuff out and you have a couple friends on TeamSpeak, I think you will have a lot of fun playing Pulsar: Lost Colony.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								The game that would result in someone getting FTL and Guns of Icarus into a bed together would be glorious.  Luckily, Leafy Games did it, and the result is glorious.  You can take control as one of five classes: Captain, Pilot, Scientist, Engineer, and Weapons Specialist.  Each one has their own upgradable abilites that help them along their journey.  Each class is also extremely fun.  Even the Scientist, who does nothing but scan ships and deploy viruses, is an intense and satisfying class.Along with fun classes are the fun scenarios.  From battling ancient sentries to bringing someone a lost sandwhich, each scenario and quest is fun.  Each scenario is also very balanced.  The bosses feel hard, but will never induce rage.  Sentry drones are easy to take out, but they are more than a mere nuisance.  You will never get bored playing this game.Possibly the best part of the game is the community.  While their are some less than mature people playing (there have been ships named the H.M.S.♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you will always be greeted by friendly space trekkers willing to help you when they can.  This is the type of game where friendships are made.All in all, this is one of the best games I've played, even though it's in Early Access.The worst part about the game are the few bugs that will most certainly be fixed in the next update.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 1, 2016
Product received for free
Early Access Review
								For all of you folks who enjoy space as much as I do, this game is a nice way to explore it. Here is the views of it and what I think of it (please keep in mind that this game is in Early Access, it is being improved as we speak and/or read).First of all, this game is a multiplayer game where you can play with friends or random people online. You are a crew aboard one of many ships to explore the vast space. Each crew member is assigned a post to fulfill. This may sound lame, but it is quite awesome. The captain gives orders, assigns missions, gives pay for the crew to use on tools and food (for healing). The pilot, well, pilots the ship (this job is my favorite, especially when fighting other ships). The engineer repairs the ship and puts out fire. He can also remove the core (not recommended unless facing death). The scientist observes the ship's status and reports any problems to the engineer. The weapon specialist can shoot the guns. Now, each crew member can do any of these roles whenever they feel like it. However, they can upgrade their talents for their specific job.Now, as of right now, all you can do in this game is to attack enemy ships (you can teleport to their ship if it is damaged enough to have its shield down and kill the crew repeatedly until you claim the ship for your own and use it), land on planets and kill creatures that try to kill you, accept quests and do them, and explore the world. However, as I previously stated, this game is in Early Access, and it will continue to improve. There are many mysteries in this game. For example, I found a random ship that was dead floating in space. When I teleported onto it (yes, you have a teleporter you use to get to the planets and other ships), I found out that it was another ship you could decide to use, and it was full of snow. It was dead, so we (my crew and I) had to leave it, but this was the only time I saw it.Two more things. First, if your ship explodes, your crew and you die. You have to restart. I like this feature. It makes you more cautious, which this game is supposed to make you feel. You need to play your role as if you are there. And finally, there is a manual for the game you can use to check up more on the game. Thanks for your time.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is in no way complete, but that doesn't detract from the fun it provides in its current beta state. Alone you can maybe play this game for around 2 hours before running out of missions and 5 hours before you realise just how little this game has to keep you preoccupied without making your own goals. I personally stop playing after the fourth hour only comming back for an extra 5-10 minutes to check out the updates. The rest was playing with my friends, and thats where this game shines the most. while single player has you locked in as captain only unable to change multiplayer lets you play around with the other classes adding some variety. Is the game worth buying as it is now? if you plan to play alone then absolutly not, with friends? maybe when it's on sale, otherwise wait for a future update with the speed they're pumping out updates it shouldn't take more than 2 years before it's well worth the full price.

								This game is the game I have been waiting for since I started playing Steam games in 2013 and now Pulsar has provided  the best space, simulation, co-op, and action game experiance you will get right now. It is based around communication between your 5-man team.Each player has its duties - Scientist: Control Cyber-Defense/Offense, scans areas of space/ships/planetsEngineer: Control Warp Drive, maintain energy to systems, controls / maintains core.Captain: Commands players, accepts/declines missions, maintains all ship systems, shops for parts, food, weapons.Master Gunmen: Controls energy to weapons, controls all ship weaponsPilot: Alligns ships to jump, manuevers ship in combat.If all players do their duties the game is great, but there are some trolls that will mess with your systems.The adventure is amazing, the action is suspensful, and its quite relaxing. 10/10

content:
Posted: April 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								Pulsar, is a great game with a great idea to it's name. It's mechanics are great, allowing you to fly around your spaceship, fire weapons, explore planets, and several other things. What makes this game even greater is mutltiplayer. It is so much easier to put hours and hours into this game, when you play with lots of friends. Even if you don't have friends to play with, there is also a great online community to go out and explore.There are somethings I don't like about the game however. One of the big things, is that the game feels unfinished. On planets there is not much to do and out in space all you really can do is fight ships. There are also several bugs with the Ai, and occasionaly other things.Besides some of these, which I believe will be worked out over time, the game is great. I specificaly bought this to play FTL, but in 3D and this game gave me exactly that!

Early Access Review
								The game does lack alot of content it could have but overall is a really fun game. The planets are tiny and rather repetitive, the boarding can often times result in the ship you are comandeering being blown up in the process and your missiles can often times turn allies into enemies because of the AOE.Understanding that the game is in Beta there is alot of content either not yet added or not yet optimized. I've often been subject to the game lagging a little in shops or had audio glitches. Sometimes you feel like there just aren't enough people to properly man the ship, like having 3 turrets but really only have 2 people who can man them permanently but only if the captain fills in rather than doing his trademark chair warming.I do recommend the game though even despite my review of it seems negative, really I'm simply warning what you should be expecting as of Beta 7.2.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								We arrive at the Citadel, a broken thing I call home, skeleton crew staffed to conduct extrasolar missions for our federation, retrieving and eliminating mostly. We hunt fugitives, set a mapped path, travel through star systems, asteroids, and planets. Bumping hulls with mass relays, xeno-bio ships, drones and enemy factions. Our mission? To retrieve lost medical supplies, save scientists and possibly encounter hostile space vessels. This is Pulsar, a game about adventures in space, where the game is buggy (read: indev alpha) but updates are plenty, and features more fulfilling than any game that you will find in this specific category of coop star-(word) film simulator. It's got an unexplainable charm of how close it mimics the star-(worded) films, it's not an exact copy of a specific one and it doesn't intend to be, but the exploration feels like star-trek TNG to me (small crew and warp drives). Every player has a role in a crew of five, some interact more with the ingame hologram HUD(s), unifying controls for managing the ship together, but separated only by distance from each role's cubicles.The captains, Dungeon Master… err, Creative Director, for the non-DnD nerds. He/she makes or breaks the adventure because of currency distribution, ship upgrades and mapped missions are all done by this role, directly impacting all other players’ experiences. The weapons specialist, novice of left mouse buttons, and experienced to QTEs (Quick Time Events), where the shot for the missile must be struck by beam weapons first to lower their shield, so the next immediate hit can directly impact their hull, bypassing their shield regeneration. The scientist is a part time script-kitty, medic, away-team lead, and first-strike team point-man. Scientists have the most utility aside from the captain.The engineer, an expert in duct-tape usage and juggling, must allocate the ship's power at its best or worse conditions, or we all explode and die.And the pilot, must dodge missiles, maneuver to mitigate damage in combat, belly up = bad, belly down = good.Best experienced with VOIP, intoxicants, video recording program, and popcorn.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								WARNING: If your ready to have to put up with role-play captains who won't let you use a fire extinguisher for no reason other than it doesn't fit roleplay, captains who if you give any kind of order to anyone they will jump on you and tell you that's not your job, captains that don't like it when you make the tiniest of mistakes, or captains who will ask you if you have teamspeak and if you say no they just kick you, get this game. If can't handle that, don't buy this game.If you've played Guns of Icarus Online, this game is pretty similar.You and 1-4 other players (along with bots) pilot a space ship, there are 5 classes and each has a unique role and do uniqe jobs. Heavy teamwork is required in order to succeed. You'll go around the universe destroying other space ships, exploring ruins, and pillaging planets. All of this is very, very fun, which is why I recommend this game.As said the only downside is the role-play/super serious sub-community that is quite idiotic and can't accept the fact that what they're playing doesn't affect them in real life by much at all...Pros:+Fun game+Team-based+Mature community+Lots of potential+Unique+Great design+Amazing space asetheticsCons:-Role-play/serious sub-community-Bad NPCs-Easy to grief-No tutorial-Not much planet depth

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								I only have a few hours under my belt, but I like what I've seen so far.Interesting game concept, designed around teamwork. Each player having their own role to perform makes everyone feel useful, to an extent. Some jobs require more attention than others, such as pilot or engineer. Obviously the game needs more content, but it is still early access, so it will come. One thing I WOULD like to see implemented though, is some sort of a job queueing system. Some players will obviously be more comfortable doing a certain role (I've only been a Scientist so far) And joining games is rolling the dice, because you're probably not going to end up in the role you would like, which can make it more difficult to gel with a new team. So it would be nice if there was a way to queue as a scientist, or pilot etc, and be shown a list of games where that role is needed.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 1, 2016
Product received for free
Early Access Review
								For all of you folks who enjoy space as much as I do, this game is a nice way to explore it. Here is the views of it and what I think of it (please keep in mind that this game is in Early Access, it is being improved as we speak and/or read).First of all, this game is a multiplayer game where you can play with friends or random people online. You are a crew aboard one of many ships to explore the vast space. Each crew member is assigned a post to fulfill. This may sound lame, but it is quite awesome. The captain gives orders, assigns missions, gives pay for the crew to use on tools and food (for healing). The pilot, well, pilots the ship (this job is my favorite, especially when fighting other ships). The engineer repairs the ship and puts out fire. He can also remove the core (not recommended unless facing death). The scientist observes the ship's status and reports any problems to the engineer. The weapon specialist can shoot the guns. Now, each crew member can do any of these roles whenever they feel like it. However, they can upgrade their talents for their specific job.Now, as of right now, all you can do in this game is to attack enemy ships (you can teleport to their ship if it is damaged enough to have its shield down and kill the crew repeatedly until you claim the ship for your own and use it), land on planets and kill creatures that try to kill you, accept quests and do them, and explore the world. However, as I previously stated, this game is in Early Access, and it will continue to improve. There are many mysteries in this game. For example, I found a random ship that was dead floating in space. When I teleported onto it (yes, you have a teleporter you use to get to the planets and other ships), I found out that it was another ship you could decide to use, and it was full of snow. It was dead, so we (my crew and I) had to leave it, but this was the only time I saw it.Two more things. First, if your ship explodes, your crew and you die. You have to restart. I like this feature. It makes you more cautious, which this game is supposed to make you feel. You need to play your role as if you are there. And finally, there is a manual for the game you can use to check up more on the game. Thanks for your time.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is really good for its current development state. Excellent multiplayer with a real emphasis on team work. There is no other game quite like it. I would like to see more games go in this direction with multipassenger ships that can move during space travel. Most space games leave out features that make them immersive. This game captures immersion almost perfectly. I would however like to see a third person mode added along with more to do on the ships. While this game has a class system unlike any other, the classes need to be fleshed out a little more, with more abilities unique to their role. I would also like to see more domestic activities implemented on the ships and an asymmetrical way of interacting with other peoples crews in other games. Overall great direction and kep adding content. With a lot more pve content this game has the potential to be one of the best space simulations out there.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								I'll fully admit that it took me a while to decide if I was going to purchase this title or not. The graphics in the screen shots and the videos made me wary that this was yet another Early Access title that does the same thing that other, bigger, prettier games do so much better. (And lets be honest, if you've played Early Access you probably know exactly what I mean.)Then, I decided that I would go on YouTube (something I never do) in order to see what the game play was actually like. What I saw intrigued me enough that I actually bought an Early Access title for what I thought was a lot of money for such a simple looking game. So far, I'm pretty amazed by what Leafy Games has managed to put together. After you play this, you'll wonder why it took so long for a game company to see space combat through a cooperative lens. The game isn't done yet, don't get me wrong, but what it does is something that no other game has really attempted with any degree of success. It takes the somewhat tried-and-true formula of a space sim/roguelike/shooter/RPG and instead of giving each player their own unique starship they make you cooperate to run that one starship well.The five classes they have in the game are mostly well balanced around one another, as each class 'controls' a particular section of the ship. Some roles, like Engineer, involve pushing buttons and pulling levers to keep the ship from overheating and providing power for the other roles to use. Science is the eyes and ears of the ship while providing offensive and defensive buffs through power allocated by the Engineer. The pilot flies the ship and collects space-loot while ensuring that they follow the captains flight plan. There's a lot there, and while it might be confusing your first game nothing is so complex that it will take more than a half-hour to learn it. (Also, the user manual is surprisingly useful for a first-time player that prefers not to engage in trial-by-fire.)The community thus far have been very helpful and nice, which is also a refreshing change of pace, although there are the obligatory trolls/children that will join into your game to shut off oxygen to your ship or purposefully start fires/destroy subsystems for the sheer hate of it. So far, they're relatively few and it's generally pretty easy to recover from any of their hijinks. It's also a small community, so after a while you'll probably know enough people to steer clear of any jokers you might encounter. Obviously, the game is growing, and really my only critique is that there needs to be a few more things that the Captain can override as far as crew decisions that could be deemed 'griefing', such as firing off nuclear warheads or turning off shields mid-combat. The game play is as fast or as slow as your group can handle. Planets are relatively relaxing without any real threat of losing anything, death is painless as you have infinite clones (Although in hardcore mode you don't get a save at all, so you better not all die at once or it's game over.), and voice chat is almost a must if you really get into this game. Bad decisions are punished hard and fast, often times without you necessarily knowing what went wrong. (Such as shooting at a -much- more powerful ship than your own, only to be one-shot in return because Science didn't bother to scan the enemy ship to determine it's relative strength.) You won't blow up out of nowhere due to any one crew members mistakes though, so don't concern yourself with the engineer accidentally ejecting the warp core or hitting the wrong button and killing everyone instantly.Most games that label themselves as 'cooperative' are anything but cooperative. This game is a breath of fresh air into the space sim genre and I hope Leafy follows through on this concept and continues their track record of timely updates and great ideas.As my last parting thought, if you're at all a fan of Star Trek and always wished there was a game that finally scratched that itch that nothing seems to satisfy, this game is literally tailor made for you. Even if you -don't- like Star Trek, this game is worth a look and a purchase just for the innovation they've already put out into the gaming universe.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								What can I say about a game I have been waiting for a very, very long time. First off the graphics; I like them. The look and feel of this game visually, is fun. some places you will visit are spooky and full of atmosphere and others are high tech.Secondly, Gameplay; I love it. It is FUN ! The ships are easy to control. Ship systems are straight forward and to the point and They are not overcomplicated which keeps the fun aspect rolling. I got the gameplay down within ten to twenty minutes. Based upon the fraction ship you choose you will be given missions which you can recieve from people at space stations. Once on said mission you may have to divert to save a fellow faction member or encounter a hostile species.Thirdly, Story; So far the main story is not there yet (BETA 11.5) but I enjoyed talking to people on space stations and via ship to ship communications. From there you are told the story of the universe which got me interested. The story is injected smoothly.I definetly recommend this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								With the right friends, this game really does seem like your own personal episode of Firefly or Star Trek.  So, here's my take on this game.The Captain ordered us to look for security drones.  We spent about 30 minutes on a search and destroy until we needed to head back and repair the hull.  I am the pilot and yes, I'm a girl.  My first attempt at docking with the repair station was ...sporty.  If you've ever seen the movie galaxy quest then you will have a good idea of what it's like to fit the destroyer into a repair station docking bay.  Our first away mission resulted in our captain yelling "Oh sh*t!" and then promptly dying.  When asked what killed him, he said something "Ambiguous" and told us to head right when we exited the terraforming station.  I headed right and immediately died by the "Ambiguous" hostile who seemed intent on shoving a plasma cannon up my posterior.  I was very happy that someone had remembered to turn on the respawning platform on board the ship.  Except for the need to change my uniform, I was ready to beam back to the planet surface and return the favor.  This game is all about friends and teamwork.  The better your team, the more fun you will have.  I wasn't happy with the price tag considering the state it's currently in but if you play this with a group of people who have a good sense of humor and a love for space operas, you will never regret the purchase.  I love this game and I see only good things to come because it's only going to get better from here.
